But Manhattan is more than a movie about love; it's about the strange effect of love in mature people. And Isaac, like Woody is mature age-wise of course.Isaac is 42, and he realizes it's an interesting age where his mind became his greatest asset, and since he evolves in an artistic milieu, he's clearly in his advantage. Through "Manhattan" and Gershwin's music, it's the whole intellectual and artistic underground world of New York that lets its soul implode, it's to New York what Saint-Germain was to Paris in the existentialist 50's. But in the 70's, New York became the center of the underground culture, of sexual liberation, of the whole questioning of the American heritage without the idealism of the late 60's or the pessimism of the post-Nixon era. Everything is debatable, war, marriage, orgasms and nothing is to be taken for granted. The film was made in 1979.

A black and white photograph can show something that one can easily miss in colour. In 'Manhattan' the black and white highlights the beauty of the city. With superb cinematography and lighting, I doubt it has looked more beautiful and captivating in any other movie. Vivacious and full of life, it looks like a place where there's always something to do and it makes me want to go there to be a part of it, at least for a while.Woody Allen does a great job of narrating using humour and sarcasm. 'Manhattan' has a very 'Annie Hall' feel to it in terms of its whimsical treatment and quirky characters. I must say I laughed out loud at the irony of his on screen relationship with 17-year-old Mariel Hemingway especially when he stresses on the age difference. Perhaps it's the whole life imitating art (in his case) since in real life, after two failed marriages, he married his ex-partner's daughter who is about 30 years younger than him.Allen himself is his usual self. Diane Keaton is terrific. Meryl Streep is sizzling hot. Mariel Hemingway is a revelation. Her performance is so nuanced and restrained that it wouldn't have even occurred to think that a newcomer is performing. Some brilliant performances indeed but the real star of 'Manhattan' is Manhattan.'Manhattan' is both a visual treat and a cinematic delight. It's a stunning look at the 70s urban culture (that is also brilliantly contrasted in 'Annie Hall'). 'Annie Hall' included with the hippie culture while 'Manhattan' revolves around the metro city culture. It's a tribute to Manhattan and its people.

I didn't see any love here at all. Not even between friends. Bunch of back stabbers. Except Tracey. Get all those people in therapy before they ruin that poor young girl. Better yet, I like to imagine she didn't fall for his lies. The film's two redeeming qualities, Gershwin and black and white Manhattan.

reviews.review_title: A deep and beautiful study, writing and portrayl of charachters.
reviews.content: My feelings and relationship with Woody Allen's movies are like the ocean tides, it comes and goes and most of the times it takes me time to digest it fully, it's like getting to know a person for the long term. Manhattan is no exception and what's nice about it is its personal and intimate slant towards the characters, it perfectly zooms into their psyche and temperament to the point where the spectator is extended to the story as he finds himself apprehending these characters, their insecurities, goodness, and qualities the same way he knows his family and close friends, but here it only takes him one hour and a half to get into their spirit. The film is also a take on the complexity of human relationships and ou fear of happiness. for example, every character keeps finding himself a justification to avoid the confrontation happiness and settling with the image they have of it for fear of getting hurt like Isaac who keeps using Tracey age as an argument to avoid commitment with her and yale using his marriage as an excuse to prevent himself from consuming his love for Marry....it's also a portrayal of how chaotic and immature adult life can be juxtaposing it with the maturity of its youngest character Tracey, a mirror of our turbulent and uncontrolled lives, and the way we disregard the happiness sitting right next to us. That's what good cinema is about; letting you see the bigger picture and detach from your universe, all this narrated and showcased in a border poetic black and white New-york, which is its most complete and definite dress.

reviews.review_title: Bergman's remake of "Sex and the city"
reviews.content: As you peek into another episode from the life of Woody Allen, the first thing you'll notice is the rich cinematography (obviously influenced by Bergman which is proved by some remarks on account of him during the film). Another thing that contributes to the overall vibe of the movie is a quality smooth jazz soundtrack.Although visually stunning and iconic, this flick does have a slight drawback which is the screenplay. Despite Allen's never disappointing deadpan humor and his natural delivery of the lines, the story does tend to get a bit predictable at times.But the thing that gives this movie its true quality is a beautiful portrayal of New York, especially in the opening sequence.

reviews.review_title: "At this point in my life, if this is the best I can do, they shouldn't give me money to make movies."
reviews.content: A forty-year-old twice-divorced man leaves his seventeen-year-old girlfriend for the mistress of his married best friend, while his ex-wife, who left him for another woman, writes a book that reveals all the details of their (sexual) life, marriage, and parting.Allen wouldn't be Allen if he didn't go to extremes, but although this sounds like a plot for a comedy, he used it for a very good study of romance and close relationships in general. In an hour and a half of this drama, imbued with his characteristic eccentric humor, which often causes discomfort rather than laughter, Allen portrayed realistic characters who, in an unsuccessful search for their own identity and fulfillment, run away from themselves through relationships. Of course, for the characters to be convincing, it is not enough just to be well written, but the performances of Allen himself in the lead role, Diane Keaton, Michael Murphy, Mariel Hemingway, and Meryl Streep do not lag behind. Add that to the beautiful black-and-white photography and music of George Gershwin performed by the New York Philharmonic led by Zubin Mehta, and we get a timeless classic. If you don't like this movie, ask yourself whether it might be because it led you to reexamine your own life which, consciously or subconsciously, you are not fulfilled with.8/10

Even setting aside Allen's personal history that inescapably boosts the creep factor of one of the central relationships, this movie is filled with utterly unlikeable people doing immoral things. Supposedly a love letter to the titular city, the only thing that rises even to admirability is the cinematography. Except for the romanticizing of the city via the look of the film, there is zero romance to any of these relationships. I will never be able to suspend disbelief at the idea, in many of Allen's films where he plays the main character, that he's somehow such an attractive Casanova that he gets himself into these predicaments to begin with. His characters are such annoying, whiny-voiced trolls. The humor is low-key, nothing laugh-out-loud funny, but a few chuckles. It's the kind of movie pseudo-intellectuals write and give glowing reviews of, but for the rest of us it's just a big shrug. If these are the types of people that are typical of Manhattanites, then screw Manhattan, and definitely this movie.

"Manhattan" isn't a bad movie movie but it is an overrated one. The problem is that after a little while, I couldn't care about what was happening. That's because the characters aren't that appealing. Mariel Hemingway is so unappealing that its impossible to see why Woody Allen is attracted to her in the first place. (She also delivers the worst performance in the movie.) There are some funny moments but not that many. I usually enjoy Black & White photography but it doesn't really work in this movie. It's more of a distraction that anything else. I first saw "Manhattan" in the theater (Bellerose, NY). I've seen it several times since. It's a middle-of-the-road (at best) Woody Allen movie. Dishonorable mention: when Woody starts kissing Hemingway in the hansom cab.

reviews.review_title: Not a bad movie, but definitely overrated.
reviews.content: Before anything, I must say that I'm not too much of a big Woody Allen fan, but some of his movies however have left a pretty great impression on me, namely "Annie Hall", "Hanna and Her Sisters" and "Crimes and Misdemeanors". Manhattan however didn't leave the same impression on me, after watching the movie, I felt kind of empty, I felt like it was missing something.Well, to start off, the relationship between Woody Allen and the 17 year-old girl hasn't aged well at all, specially after all the accusations against Woody by Mia Farrow. But that aside, the movie just wasn't as funny as Annie Hall, It made me smirk once in a while, but no scene made me truly laught out loud, I also thought that Woody's character here was even more annoying than in Annie Hall. I was also expecting far more of the cinematography, every review I read of this movie stated that the cinematography is magnificent, a masterpiece, but aside from the great opening, which I admit it was marvelous, I feel like the movie didn't show that much of Manhattan at all, I was definitely expecting more on the visual deparmtment.Overall as I said, not a bad movie, but I was definitely expecting much more from the great reviews that I read before watching the movie. I'd give it 6.5/10 if I was allowed, since I don't have this option, I'll give it a 6/10.

reviews.review_title: One of Woody Allen's best movies
reviews.content: I love Manhattan. Seriously, this is far better than Annie Hall (okay, not everyone may agree) and it's a movie I can watch regularly. Sure, some are critical of it being in black and white, but that gives it the necessary charm to be a classic. Manhattan is timeless.If you're a devotee of Fast and the Furious, then this movie isn't for you so please move on.The way Woody Allen explores the interweaving relationships is revealing and even entertaining. The Gershwin soundtrack gives it the necessary sweeping emotional landscape. For those who like Manhattan, you have to see Manhattan Murder Mystery, you won't be disappointed.

This is a very good, not great, Woody Allen movie. The best parts are the sights of NY and that glorious music. The music underscoring is perfect for selected scenes. A romantic dramady that sure to please most of Woodys fans.I do have a couple of nit-picks. First, what ever happened to Diane Keatons dog? The dog is in a couple of scenes, but then disappears. When she's away and staying at Allens home, where is the dog? Does she have a dog walker or keeper. Things like this should be explained. Another nit-picker is that of the character of his 17 year old girl friend. She's under age for heaven sake which makes him a pervert. No one takes note of that. And where oh where are her parents? She's out a night...stays with him overnight, yet nothing is said of her parents. Don't they wonder or even ask where she's been all the time? That part of the story as well as the dog issue make the story a little unbelievable and unrealistic. Other than that, MANHATTAN is quite a good film.

It's already well known that Woody Allen is pretty creepy. This movie really drives that home. Casting yourself as an adult man going after a high school girl is obviously weird in the eyes of a normal person, and it isn't any better than it sound when it comes to "Manhattan". It's incredibly hard to get past that and enjoy the movie.Manhattan does a lot of things right from a technical perspective. The camera work and shots are gorgeous and the subject matter of a 70's New York is cozy and romantic. However, the characters in this film fall flat for me. I find myself struggling to care about them, and it's not just because I'm focused on hoping Tracey escapes her relationship with Isaac. The characters are also plain annoying to an aggravating point and lots of the humor misses for me.

Woody Allen is certainly the best director of Woody Allen films who ever lived. And this is one of his best, which I have just seen again, and it is as fresh as when it was made. He wrote this clever and poignant script jointly with Marshall Brickman, an old chum of Woody's who wrote SLEEPER (1973) and ANNIE HALL (1977), and later wrote MANHATTAN MURDER MYSTERY (1993), thus being a Woody collaborator for more than 20 years. (Strangely, Brickman has written three feature films with Manhattan in the title, since he also wrote a serious film about the making of the atom bomb, THE MANHATTAN PROJECT, in 1986, which was very good. Some people just can't escape the island, even to get as far as Brooklyn.) The schoolgirl girlfriend of Woody, Tracy, is played by the 18 year-old Mariel Hemingway, with charming innocence. She matured into a very interesting 'grownup', and I am one of those who bewailed the failure to continue the wonderful TV series CENTRAL PARK WEST (1995), in which she starred, leaving us all holding our breath after 13 episodes and never getting to find out what happened next. Until MAD MEN, it was one of the finest drama series ever done on American television. Tisa Farrow has a very funny bit part and a good comic line. Former New York Congresswoman and leading feminist Bella Abzug, who was famous at that time (she died in 1998), appears briefly as herself, which caused a stir at the time. Today probably few remember her, but whether you were in agreement with her political views or not, all agreed she was one of the great 'characters' of the political scene of those days. Diane Keaton is wonderfully, comically neurotic, and as brilliant as ever. Woody himself stops wisecracking long enough from time to time to show real pathos, especially at the end. Meryl Streep, with long silky hair and a long sulky face, has a rather thankless role as his vicious ex-wife. Is there anyone who has not seen this film? The film has the usual great gags and 'oh, that hurts!' satire running all the way through. It is also an Ode to New York, luxuriating in wonderful shots of some of Woody's favourite views of his favourite city. The music of Gershwin is used throughout, and one of the classic scenes of American cinema is near the beginning where 'Rhapsody in Blue' reaches a crescendo just as fire works explode from the Manhattan skyline at night. The film is really a love letter to New York written, directed, and acted with passion by all of them. The whole cast and the whole gang were young and full of joie de vivre, and it shows. This film will never age. It is still 17, like Tracy, and it will never grow up. And thank God for that.

reviews.review_title: "My therapist warned me about her. So I found a different therapist."
reviews.content: 'Manhattan' is perhaps the most highly acclaimed movie of Allen's, and compliments of my local library, I finally got around to seeing the B&W version on DVD. This B&W version is much better than the version printed on color film, as it gives the city a more abstract look. Allen plays his usual character, a wise-cracking neurotic who likes to date younger women. The object of his affection here is played expertly by Mariel Hemingway, who indeed was only 17 when filming began. While it is a fine film about relationships and the difficulty thereof, it seems to be certainly overrated, compared to other fine films. It also requires one to enjoy the typical Woody Allen dialog, which achieves a certain sameness from movie to movie. Many will explicitly NOT enjoy an endless stream of it.  I like it most of the time, however it DOES get tiresome. Still, a good story.However, my favorite Allen movie remains "The Purple Rose of Cairo" which to me stands above all his others. Regarding the actual story in 'Manhattan', the critic Ebert has a complete description and I will repeat none of it here.

reviews.review_title: Very possibly the best B&W movie in the modern era
reviews.content: First of all I have to say that I am biased. I just love Woody Allen movies. But what is different about this movie, the thing that sets above most other Woody Allen movies, is the B&W photography. While the writing and then dialogue is wonderful, this is a movie that you can watch with the sound off. That is with the exception of the Gershwin score which is wonderful.

This is definitely a great film depicting great scenes filmed throughout the City of New York and involved Isaac Davis, (Woody Allen) who was a man who had three bad marriages and one son. Isaac was a television producer and writer and lost one of his wives because she left the marriage for another woman. Meryle Streep, (Jill Jones) was the woman who left and his son was born from Jill, who had parental visitations with the boy and his father. Jill also decides to write a book about her marriage and in this book she tells everything horrible about poor Isaac. Isaac decides to quit his television job and decides to write a book but in the meantime he meets up with a seventeen year old girl, Tracy,( Mariel Hemingway) who gives an outstanding performance with her great acting. Mary Wilkie,(Diane Keaton) is another girl that he falls in love with and always seems to be a very confused man who is trying to find a woman who loves him. George Gershwin music was played as background music throughout this film which made this film very enjoyable with a great cast of actors and plenty of laughter. Enjoy.

reviews.review_title: One performance elevates it from good to great
reviews.content: "Manhattan" is an American movie from 1979, so this one has its 40th anniversary this year. It was directed and co-written by Woody Allen, who also plays Isaac, the central character. Despite how old it already is, this is not one of Allen's earliest works by any means. He was already in his 40s at that point and so was his character. It is a black-and-white movie and while I usually like these, it did not make too much of an impact on me here that there was no color. But there are enough other reasons why people should watch and will most likely appreciate this film. It is also not really where the movie is set. Honestly, it could have been in all kinds of other places than New York and the story and impact would not have been any different. There is only a brief reference towards the end when we hear Isaac give a certain quote that basically refers to his own writing, but obviously can also be understood as a reference to the characters in this movie made by Allen himself. Yes, Isaac is a writer. But it does not really matter too much. We find out about the characters' professions and job backgrounds only because they are linked to their relationships with each other. This is really typical Allen overall. There is no character development, hardly any changes away from these relationships. The few changes there are like the young girl's ambitions to move to London are only included because they are really relevant in terms of her relationship with the protagonist. But on the other side, there is so much going on in terms of relationships from beginning to end that it almost seems too much for a film with this running time.Allen recast his muse Diane Keaton for a supporting role here not too long after the Annie Hall triumph. Also this movie here takes place in New York. Then there is Meryl Streep around the time when she won her first Oscar when she was barely 30. Anne Byrne Hoffman does not have too much screen time, but she does fine with what she was given I think. The only other male in here with more screen time than a few seconds is Michael Murphy who plays the protagonist's best friend, but also a rival. But the one who deserves the biggest mention is the really young Mariel Hemingway who was just as young as the character she played, namely 17/18. Today they would have cast a 23-year-old actress I suppose, but not back then. She is really tremendous and I am glad she received an Oscar nomination for her portrayal and as she did not have much precursor attention, it looks like a sweet surprise. I think she was better than big names Streep and Keaton and that says quite something. Certainly the role of her lifetime, the mix of a Lolita character with an innocent schoolgirl crushing on a much older man, but really more of the latter. She was a complete scene stealer every time she was on and there is a reason why she gets the last scene of the movie (apart from the first scene too). The break-up scene is really heartbreaking, the final departure scene is pretty memorable too and this was when I decided that this film deserves more than three stars out of five. Without her, I probably would not have given four. Also a really cool and likable character with her acting background and film knowledge. She is just as sweet as it gets. We also only see the film from Ike's perspective and everybody is gentle about this relationship. You could definitely wonder what they were talking behind his back about it. As for her character and her relationship to Ike, it is a constant up and down. Pay attention to how he even forgets her 18th birthday. Really sad stuff. It may sound funny how he says she talks like Jerry's cousin, but it is kinda disrespectful if we take a closer look because he knows about her insecurities in terms of age and still says stuff like that, but she is really crazy about him. No idea why though.I would say that Allen here plays a pretty unlikable character and even if he does not deserve all the hate and lies he is getting (like mostly from Streep's character), you also never really feel sorry for him, for example also when the woman leaves him after earlier saying she sees a man in him who could be the father of her children. And still she goes back to the married husband who eventually decides to leave his wife for her. Now back to the final scene: Even the 18-yo eventually steps up for herself and honestly I am so glad he did and it was a bit of a happy ending. It was also really desperate by Allen's character trying to convince her to stay in New York after what he said earlier, namely that she absolutely should leave. It could ruin her future honestly if she gave up on that great study opportunity. But he sure is a bit of an egomaniac. Still he gets played by everybody somehow in the end. But his reaction is not aggressive. Aggression is not really a factor in this film. It would have been in many others with similar story lines. But it would also have felt a bit unusual for Allen, at least back then.Instead, it is all about swallowing it and trying to make the most of it. We won't know what happens after half a year. Will Ike have found somebody else and lost interest in the girl again? Will she have found somebody in London and decide to stay there? Possible. But maybe they really end up as a couple after this half year, even if at least from Ike's perspective I just cannot see him stay faithful for years if not decades. I mean let's just imagine that Keaton's character expressed an interest in him again. I think he would go back to her right away somehow. It's all open. Everything is possible. Aside from that, as most other times with Allen, this film is really dialogue-driven, some truly smart moments in here and I can see why this was nominated for an Oscar. Not undeservingly. Certainly not a case of oh it's Allen again, he always writes good scripts, so just give him another nod. He deserves it. I also don't really care about his private affairs and love life and if you take that as a reason to strip yourself off the experience of seeing this movie, then you are making a mistake. You don't have to like him as a human. I mean you don't even know him as a human. Just try to appreciate his art. And there is really a great deal of it he left us and is still coming up with in his 80s now. This one here is definitely a contender for his best career effort. I enjoyed it a lot at times. Go watch it and pay attention to how really this is such an open-minded film when it comes to all kinds of unusual romantic involvements (not today anymore, but back in the 1970s for sure). Also a great watch to check out with your significant other.

Woody Allen aka Mr.Cinema's 'Manhattan' is a Beautifully Written & Directed Film, that will leave you smiling, due to it's never-ending charm.'Manhattan' Synopsis: A divorced New Yorker currently dating a high-schooler brings himself to look for love in the mistress of his best friend instead.'Manhattan' begins & ends in a very mature, yet complicated manner. Allen is the Greatest Story-Teller of his time & 'Manhattan' is among his best films. It's simply unforgettable work.Allen & Marshall Brickman's Screenplay is wonderful. Allen's direction, like always, is sublime. Cinematography & Editing, are perfect. Performance-Wise: Allen delivers a fantastic performance. Mariel Hemingway is bombastic, while Diane Keaton is dependable, as always. Meryl Streep is graceful. Michael Murphy is impressive.On the whole, 'Manhattan' is a must see.

So wrote the great poet Keats, and so the great director Woody Allen filmed this, his masterpiece, to achieve this goal.Though he did go on to scale similar heights a few years later with Hannah and Her Sisters, this I feel is his best movie. With two bold strokes apparent from the opening minutes: black and white cinematography and Gershwinn's Rhapsody in Blue on the soundtrack as fireworks blaze across the city's skyline - Woody casts a spell as powerful and romantic as a film can give us. The opening glow lingers for the rest of the movie as his character stumbles through his crazy-quilt patchwork of relationships - until he is finally stopped in his tracks by the simple, innocent kindness and wisdom of Mariel Hemingway's character. Is it possible for someone not attracted to urban life to flip for this movie? What would a rural fellow or lass make of such a hymn of praise to our great metropolis? And to think Woody made this in the 70's when NYC was not the relatively safe place it is these days. And what sort of story does he tell here? Is it about politics, crime, any number of socially relevant issues? No, it's a Woody Allen movie, so it's a romantic comedy - with one important difference. It's the greatest one ever made.

reviews.review_title: A love letter to a city
reviews.content: Manhattan is Woody Allen's tribute to his city. His love of New York is a constant factor throughout his work, and here it is crystallised. Shot in black and white, the excellent photography has a retro feel that captures the city in the classic monochrome style that suits NYC so well. While it recalls the imagery of 1940's movies Manhattan is hardly a retrogressive film. It's chief strength is the way is combines the classic visual presentation and George Gershwin tunes with a modernist approach. The way it lovingly incorporates New York locations into its story about angst-ridden urban types. The narrative about a set of New Yorkers struggling with the complexity of human relationships is rich in characterisations, replete with wit and is overall a considerably sophisticated urban comedy-drama.Manhattan is often compared to Annie Hall, although in my view it doesn't reach the standard of that comedy classic. It is though a much more conventionally structured film than the non-linear and wildly inventive techniques used in that earlier film. On the other hand Manhattan has a more realistic approach that the more conventional narrative benefits. Although this doesn't mean that the film is overly serious. Hardly. Allen himself has many funny lines, and the comedy in general is very good. Its just that its central story of infidelity and the difficulties of male/female relationships is one that has a few serious minded moments that gives pause for thought.Overall, Manhattan is Woody Allen's most visually striking film. His most cinematic. It benefits a lot from being experienced on the big screen. It isn't his best but its amongst his best. Its the point where he started making serious but funny comedy-dramas. And of course its a love letter to Manhattan that skilfully incorporates many of the locations on that island into its story in a way that celebrates them independently of the narrative. If you have any love of this amazing city, you could do worse than try Manhattan.

reviews.review_title: Scarcely has bleakness been so enjoyable
reviews.content: Woody Allen's Manhattan is proof that the smallest things do in fact make a film great, even when they're put to use in a projects that seems as if it could do no wrong. To put it simply, this is a glorious film, that utilizes character development, poignancy, deep thought, personal flaws, and love to tell a story that is one for the history books of cinema.The film focuses on forty-two year old, comedy writer Isaac Davis (Woody Allen) who is going out with seventeen year old Tracy (Mariel Hemingway). Tracy views their relationship as a precocious one that is directly built off of love. Isaac views it as a passing diversion that will soon be forgotten by the both of them. Isaac feels as if he is the last thinking man in a world that is made up of a cesspool of idiots and pseudo-intellectual mouthbreathers. He winds up meeting Mary Wilkie (Diane Keaton), who rubs him the wrong way at first, but eventually begins to grow on him for her the intelligence she provides and the waves of passion that seemingly flow off her body.Isaac still continues his relationship with Tracy, even though, at this point, why bother? He personally believes it will go nowhere. Tracy clings to hope that it will go somewhere and frets over the idea it won't and, in the end, feels as if she will soon be facing a dark inevitability of life. The only thing seemingly stopping Isaac from going all the way with Mary is that she is currently dating his friend Yale (Michael Murphy) is dating her. But, then again, it doesn't stop him so much to become romantically invested with her, spending all the time in the world and even having sex; so what is exactly stopping him.This is when Manhattan becomes one of the most involved pictures Allen has ever made. Nothing is truly stopping Isaac, but he is paranoid over small details and sees most everything as either trivial (his relationship with Tracy) or effectively makes it achieve a level of intimacy and success that cannot be passed (his relationship with Mary). Isaac wants his relationship with Mary to pass unfathomable heights that may not exist in reality, and his attachment to Tracy is one out of pure convenience. He is in dire need of a wake up call.Not many filmmakers could portray a relationship between a forty-year-old and a teenager to such great power and believability, and with Woody Allen's reputation as of now, one entering this picture blindly could base the premise too much on reality. The fact is he does a brilliant job taking a controversial subject into light. The scene at the diner between Isaac and Tracy, among many other things, is terrific and captivating and accentuates truly what Allen is about in making deeply involved human dramas.Combine the plot and character elements of the film with amazing black and white photography by Gordon Willis and an amazingly elegant score by George Gershwin and you have a picture that delights on every level for your senses. It's extremely rare a film hit many areas of a film on the head with such confidence and style, but Woody Allen's Manhattan does it and does it boldly, making this one of the best romantic films I have yet to see.Starring: Woody Allen, Diane Keaton, Mariel Hemingway, and Michael Murphy. Directed by: Woody Allen.

reviews.review_title: Woody Allen's movies ooze class, from the breathtaking jazz scores to the Ralph Lauren cloathing, elevated dilogue and georgous black and white cinematography
reviews.content: Woody Allen's movies ooze class, from the breathtaking jazz scores to the Ralph Lauren cloathing, elevated dilogue and georgous black and white cinematography, Manhattan is a Rolls Royce of a movie. Woody's neurotic, dorky everyman is just magnetic everytime he's othe screen as is his chemistry with Diane Keaton which enables the scipt to just allow conversations to take center stage with little need for any major plot developments. The music here is everything with George Gerswin's jazz score setting the tone right from the outset and dictating the pacing of the movie and its conversations, even to those unfamiliar with the genre the atompshere it sets is warm, fresh and classic. Coming in at only 90 minutes Mahattan is a firecracker of a movie and has a strong argument for being Allen's greatest achievement.

Woody Allen's really boring style (the narrative, the dialogues, the script, the irritating pseudo-intellectualism), added to not very interesting characters and with questionable character choices that don't make us empathize at all.

reviews.review_title: There is this devastating satirical piece on that on the Op-Ed page of the Times
reviews.content: Woody Allen is a great director, and Manhattan is his masterpiece. It's a bitingly funny, touching romantic comedy and a two-faced paean to Woody's hometown. Annie Hall might steal the spotlight but, for me, Manhattan is the cream of Woody Allen's crop. Watching Manhattan, you become aware of just how much Woody loves these characters and this city--especially in his refusal to idealize them. Everyone has their foibles, as does the city, but they're all drawn with remarkable care. Yes, Yale is a lout and Isaac is narcissistic, but we, like Woody, like them anyway because they're just human and, in fact, they mean well. The city too is not perfect, but it has its perfect aspects. I feel as though there are nerves laid bare, and I feel closer to the filmmaker in Manhattan. Annie Hall is wonderful and sophisticated for a romantic comedy, but it incorporates too many gags typical of Allen's earlier films. While something like sneezing on a coke-mirror is funny, it seems out of place among the complex emotions and bittersweet tales in Annie Hall. Allen's gags are always funny, but they worked better in the overall narratives of movies like Bananas and Sleeper and Take the Money and Run. Manhattan, I think, eschews those types of laughs for something more mature and satirical. There are laughs and gibes, but they seem more organic inasmuch as they more or less come out of Woody's mouth. The jokes appear as part of his character and not like something added onto the movie to make it funnier. Oh, and it's probably the most wonderfully shot of Allen's films. Allen is an auteur, but you feel his presence not through any visual characteristics of his films--you feel it in story and character types. Manhattan is gorgeous to watch; it makes Manhattan magical. Maybe it's just because it was shot in black-and-white (Gordon Willis, the cinematographer, also shot Annie Hall and Interiors, among other Allen films). No, I don't think that's it. Manhattan takes its time studying the landscape; it looks beyond the characters. There are sweeping vistas that add a dimension to this film different from Allen's other movies--a sense of geography and place. Annie Hall, for all its east coast vs. west coast barbs, was never terribly concerned with landscape. As the title of this film makes plain, the city becomes a central figure in the story of the various love affairs we encounter on screen. All in all, this is a great little gem and one that you should see if you like Woody Allen, romantic comedies, or, really, movies.

reviews.review_title: Visually striking love letter to Manhattan
reviews.content: "Manhattan" was always one of those movies I admired more than I liked. I had seen it several times, the first being when I was 14, and had always found the relationship between Tracy and Isaac uncomfortable to watch, the characters far less well-drawn than in Allen's best work, and the film great to look at but lacking in much else.Well, it's been a few years since I saw it last and I'd like to think that I've matured as a person and in terms of my appreciation for film and understanding of it. So what do I think of "Manhattan" now? Well, it looks even more gorgeous than I remember, with the cinematography by Gordon Willis really standing out to me this time. It's possibly his best work (which is saying something given his credentials), and it is only enhanced by Allen's wonderful shot compositions and beautiful portraits of the Manhattan skyline. I did notice this time that most of the outdoor shooting seems to have taken place during sunrise or sunset, which helps give the city the ethereal, mythic quality Allen was going for with the black and white aesthetic (a point made very clear in the narration at the start of the film). The images here are wonderful, evocative, and just beautiful.I'll gladly admit that I'm attracted to good-looking 17 year olds, but I'm still in my twenties and if I'm forty-two and still have the same feelings I would never consider dating someone that age simply out of responsibility (the 'love is ageless' argument would work if it was actually love, but I don't think there's much of that in this particular case). That's a problem a lot of people have with this film, and it was one of my major issues with it as well, especially given that Isaac repeatedly refers to her as a child and recognizes her immaturity. It's one of the reasons that this aspect of the film will never work for me. I always understood what Allen was going for with the character (that the relationship was meant to be a reflection of Isaac's own immaturity and dependency on childish impulses, as is pointed out in the final scene with him telling Tracy "don't be so mature!"), but it still disturbs me slightly, and I'll never be able to get past that. The rest of the film I'm fine with, but even the rest of the script is nowhere near as accomplished as Allen could be. Allen has always seen this film as one of his weaker efforts, and I can understand why (although I wouldn't necessarily agree). It's a fairly shallow script with fairly shallow characters, and the film works better as visual spectacle than anything else. Sure, its psychological subtext is sharp and perceptive at times, and it's quite funny, hilarious in places even, but it's not a great screenplay overall. It should be, but it isn't, probably because it simply doesn't work as a romance. Isaac may not be intended to be a pleasant character (I'm fairly certain Allen intended him to seem like the whiny bitch he is), but when you're building a dramedy around a character you should make the character interesting. Isaac may be a well-drawn character with some depth, but he's also just a completely uninteresting person, and he has nothing to add to the film, despite being the central character."Manhattan" is a good film. Nearly excellent, in fact. There are too many flaws for me to ignore, though, and although I'll always enjoy the stunning images set to Gershwin and the generally wonderful performances, there's always that script that's so perceptive and smart and creative in places, but so flawed and hackneyed in others that it gets frustrating to witness this flawed gem that could have so easily been a masterpiece.7.5/10

reviews.review_title: " Trouble? Don't worry, my middle name is trouble "
reviews.content: Although New York city is a hubbub of sophisticated culture, Gerwin music and the home of many of its citizens, there are equally as many who have left the East and journeyed to the middle West and West Coast because it is, what it is. To the movie lover, this film called " Manhattan " is so slow to catch the audience, that we are virtually awaken by the time the storyline catches up to it's intent. Here we have a collection of New Yorks oddest creatures. First we have our star Woody Allen who plays Isaac, a divorced writer, compulsive neurotic who knows what kind of woman he loves but confuses the audience with endless rhetorical recitations on the kind of woman he needs. Then there's his best friend Yale, who is definitely married, but having an affair with an attractive single woman, who desires Isaac but is attracted to Yale. Although he states he loves her, he can't commit to a divorce from his wife Mary (Diane Keaton) whom he does not want to leave. Tracy (Mariel Hemingway) plays a 17 year-old who claims she's in love with Isaac, but rebuffed, despite the fact he's had sex with her. Then there's Jill (Meryl Streep) who divorced Isaac and went lesbian, apparently to agitate Isaac. All in all, the group is a mental college of apples and oranges who should be fitted for straight jackets and not allowed out after dark in Manhatten. ***

Directed by Woody Allen. Starring Woody Allen, Diane Keaton, Mariel Hemingway, Michael Murphy, Anne Byrne, Meryl Streep, Michael O'Donoghue, Karen Ludwig. (R)Slightly more serious and grounded companion piece with "Annie Hall" is another bittersweet NYC-set story of romance, intellectualism, neuroses, flakiness and regret. Arranged as a love letter to both the city he calls home and the George Gershwin music that colors his memories (they're each as much a character as any flesh-and-blood person onscreen), and shot in gorgeous black and white by Gordon Willis, it's one of Woody's finest films in terms of visuals and music alone; that it's also a perceptive and witty character examination is the icing on the cake. Keaton is the mistress of the best friend (Murphy) that Woody falls for; Hemingway is the patient and sophisticated seventeen-year-old student he's involved with at the outset (arguably the more mature one in the couple); Streep is his ex-wife writing a tell-all book about their relationship. Falters only at the end with an underwhelming final conversation that lacks the resolving grace notes to hold together everything that came before it. Wallace Shawn amuses in a bit part (his feature film debut); Karen Allen, Frances Conroy and David Rasche can also be seen briefly.90/100

reviews.review_title: Don't watch "Manhattan" - go drink one instead
reviews.content: I had always heard that this was a great movie, so I taped it off of PBS a while ago, and only last night got around to watching it (because, unfortunately, Scare Tactics on the Sci-Fi channel wasn't on...)Boy, where do I begin? This movie is such a giddy mess, "lead" by the more-annoying-than-funny Woody Allen, that I struggled to stick with it to the end. (Even at 44, W.A. reminds one of the 14-year-old dweeb in junior high that you could never seem to ditch.)Oh, "Manhattan" has its redeeming moments: here and there a few lovely shots of New York City (done in beautiful black and white), plus some great excerpts of Gershwin tunes (a *soundtrack listing here on IMDb would have been nice - in the music credits section of the movie, the print was so tiny I couldn't read the titles!). But other than that, this film is a hodge-podge of neurotic, uninteresting, dysfunctional and unlikable people, all engaged in either outright illicit romantic activities, or just unconventional ones; oh, and they like to go to museums and theater and other artsy activities.And if Woody Allen seems childish in this film, then Mariel Hemingway, his teenage girlfriend, comes across as almost infantile. Makes one wonder why the vice squad didn't confiscate all copies of this film.So do yourself a favor and don't watch this film unless you want to be annoyed for about an hour and a half of your life. Don't watch it unless you like to see 40-something nerds shack up with teenage girls. Don't watch it unless you want to question why such films get such high accolades from film critics (who ARE those guys??). Better yet, instead of watching "Manhattan", go make yourself one: bourbon with a splash of vermouth and a dash of bitters, served with a maraschino cherry... Drink. Enjoy. Repeat.*Note - for those who want to skip the movie and just get the music, there IS a soundtrack available. Search Amazon.com or use your search engine and you will find it. In spite of not liking the movie, I do recommend the soundtrack album.

What I liked: A love letter to New York, the city looks beautiful in this film all shot in black and white. There's some funny lines. This film seems to have been replicated a lot since but I don't know how much of an original this was at the time. Good pop culture references. I think this film could really work for people who are into Rom Coms.What I disliked: I think it expects you to sympathise with the characters but I didn't at all. Woody Allen's character is extremely self absorbed and unlikable, and the other characters are pretentious. That's a big problem as you're supposed to see yourself in Woody Allen's character and sympathise with him but I despised him. This lead to me having no connection or interest in the relationships. It follows a pretty cookie cutter romantic comedy plot, whether or not this was original at the time i'm not sure, but it's definitely not the first romantic comedy so I doubt it. I also didn't find it funny for the most part but then I don't find much funny. Lastly it's about a relationship with a 17 year old which is pretty uncomfortable viewing given Woody Allen's sexual abuse allegations against a child.

Does anyone open a film better than Woody Allen? Whether it be a brilliant opening scene giving the viewer an idea of what is to follow or a fantastic opening monologue, Woody Allen has the ability to bring me into his films in their opening seconds like no other filmmaker can. Manhattan opens with that signature perfect voice- over narration that I am starting to associate with Woody Allen. Manhattan was my 6th outing with the auteur and one that I am immeasurably thankful for. There was a time in my life before I saw Manhattan and the time of my life after I saw Manhattan; the line distinguishing those two points in my life is becoming quite clear. There's nothing I like more than watching a film and knowing immediately it is going to have a profound impact on your life as a cinephile. I rarely have that experience with most films making themselves known as turning points in my life long after their credits roll. Manhattan was the 1979 installment of prolific director Woody Allen's film-a-year career. Detailing the feelings of love's uncertainty in a remarkably down to earth way, Manhattan is beautiful in no small part to its simplicity.Isaac (Woody Allen) is a forty-something writer who has a better romantic relationship with his hometown of Manhattan than he ever has with a woman in his life. Isaac is currently carrying on a relationship with a 17-year old girl that he is only half invested in because he sees the relationship as doomed to fail due to their age difference. His partner Tracy (Mariel Hemingway), however, is fully invested in their romance and realizes that she is falling in love with Isaac. After dealing with an ex-wife who divorced Isaac after realizing she was a lesbian deciding to write a book about their marriage, quitting his job as a writer for a television comedy, and believing he may be romantically interested in the woman his best friend is having an affair with, Isaac ends his relationship with Tracy in hopes of a revelation through self- discovery and a relationship with a woman his age. Isaac soon realizes that there does not exist one universal formula for a successful life, and even if there did, he probably wouldn't be satisfied with it.Woody Allen is one of my favorite filmmakers. The way he can weave a story through a theme of the uncertainty of the self and the meaning of life has always pleased this existentialist. Woody Allen manages to bring these issues to every film I've seen of his thus far in a new and innovative way which has inspired me to work my way through his entire filmography. What I was not prepared for before I watched Manhattan was how beautiful of a film Woody Allen is capable of. There are certain themes one conjures up when considering Woody Allen, among them, neurotic Jewish characters, self-aware nervous individuals, death, and bitingly quick film writing. I was pleasantly surprised just how gorgeous Manhattan was. Making the decision to shoot the film in black and white and providing subtly brilliant shots shows Allen's prowess as a director. Certain shots have stayed with me since I finished the film two days ago, for instance, the lighting in the planetarium scene when Isaac is trying to decide how he feels about his new muse, the shot through the blinds when Isaac is on the phone, Tracy sitting on the couch in the left corner of the screen as Isaac descends a set of stairs from the right corner of the screen, the shot of the couple on Isaac's television show seen arguing through wires from the ceiling, and of course the iconic shot of the Queensboro Bridge which adorns the film's poster, are all images that are beautiful in what they convey in each moment of the film--and images I can't forget. Woody Allen asks a serious question in Manhattan--"What makes life worth living", well, part of my answer is: Woody Allen films.

reviews.review_title: who could ask for anything more?
reviews.content: This is my favorite Woody Allen film and I have them all.Its a magical film shot in black and white in the most atmospheric way. Its shot with great love of the city of New York and of the characters therein. The score by Gershwin is sheer perfection and makes it a work of genius.Its an extremely funny film, which switches between humor and pathos, and has that bitter sweet quality that I love in most of his films. He deserved the Oscar nod for it and should have received it. Oddly enough its not Woodys favorite, of his many works of sheer sublime genius. But I feel its his best. From Annie Hall and Play It Again Sam to Hannah and Her Sisters straight through to Manhatten Murder Mystery and The Curse of the Jade Scorpion. All of them gems.For those of you who haven't seen the film, its essentially about an ensemble cast dealing with relationships and the fear of missing out on what might have been, rather than appreciating what you have. Of course there is love lost and love found and back again.The Cast is excellent from Dianne Keaton to Meryl Streep and a very young but excellent Hemmingway. The film is really an homage to Woody's New York and his love of Gershwin and the films of the 30's are very visible in this film.I don't want to spoil the film if you haven't seen it and if you have watch it again, it worth watching again and again. Its vintage woody.

Manhattan is often considered Woody Allen's magnum opus, his great work that has been praised by critics and audiences alike, earning Oscars and a place on the IMDb Top 250 list.Isaac Davis (Allen) is a TV comedy writer who wants to write the great American novel. Despite being 42 and twice divorced he is dating a 17-year-old old girl, Tracey (Mariel Hemingway). His ex-wife Jill (Meryl Streep), who left him for another woman, is writing a book about the breakdown of their marriage and after Isaac quits his job he is left cash poor. Despite his relationship with Tracey, Isaac starts to full for another woman, the intelligential but pretentious Mary (Diane Keaton). But she is a woman who is already in a relationship with Isaac's friend, Yale (Michael Murphy).Manhattan is a great looking film with its black and white cinematography highlighting the city, particularly when we get to see the skyline. Combined with Allen's directional approach of long takes and tracking shots gave the film a very classical feel. Allen is very good at letting a conversation flow and letting the actors interact and reaction off each other.Allen assembles an excellent cast who play their roles perfectly. They all worked well together and were very believable, even Hemingway as nice, a little naïve teenager who is somehow in a relationship with a man 25 years her senior. Streep role was small but was the professional she always is and Keaton was very different to her role in Annie Hall.When compared to Allen's previous film Annie Hall Manhattan is much more grounded and it is more of a drama then a comedy. There are some funny lines but they are much sparer. But there are some comparisons to Annie Hall, we have similar characters like Yale being a little like Rob in Annie Hall and Allen continues his assault on both mainstream TV comedy and pretentiousness. Like Annie Hall attacks Allen pretentious intelligentialism when talking about art and Allen has a continued love for Ingmar Bergman: but Allen's character is equally as pretentious as Mary yet he gets a free pass.Isaac comes up across as a very selfish and narcissistic character, he only cared about himself and willing to step over other people for his interests. All the characters selfish as they have affairs with each other and want to have the best of both worlds, like Yale who wants Mary whilst stay with his wife. SPOILER: I felt that Isaac's wanting to be with Tracey at the end was a very selfish and basically picked because he just wanted to be with somewhere. Only Tracey comes off in a good light because she has an idealised view of romance and relationships, willing to do anything for Isaac before gaining experience and knowledge from the relationship.I can see why people do like the film but I personally felt it was overrated. Compared to Annie Hall Manhattan lacked heart and passion and felt a much colder film. It is higher to sympathise with the characters in this looser narrative that film has to offer.

reviews.review_title: The intellectual Version of a Love Comedy
reviews.content: (Minor spoilers ahead) Actually, it's needless to say anything on both the story, it's characters, it's actors, their performance, cinematography, dialogs and so on, since the status of Manhattan as a classic cannot be doubted. What makes this film special is that it not only combines Allens great wit as actor, director and screenwriter with the congenial music of Gershwin and the black and white pictures of New York; it will stay with the viewer for it's deep melancholy that accompanies the characters throughout the film. How often does it happen that a comedy - and especially one concerning love, relationship, break-ups - is presented in such an intelligent, memorial and funny, but yet serious way? Hardly ever. Allen does not try to depict realistic relations, but instead delivers a sort of modern urban fairy tale in which the characters try their various strategies to cope with life - all of them behaving in their very own way. Allens character Isaac, who is totally different to that of Michael Murphy, playing his friend Yale; and yet, it's no less different to the other persons in close relation to him. Keaton and Allen become close by being the total opposite, a difference which seems to vanish, only to return in the end. Tracey, Mariel Hemingways character, in her young age is different again, not matching with Isaacs interests or perspectives, nor is his ex-wife, played by Meryl Streep. Still there is a connection. Still Allen manages to create an atmosphere in which it all fits together. Although this review may sound much more serious that the film actually is, I couldn't finish it without declaring the final scene one which will be kept in your memory as a outstanding achievement. It captures all the melancholy presented in the pictures, dialogs and music in a few minutes time. If the genre 'love comedy' exists, then this scene alone makes Manhattan the number one on my scale for that category.

Woody Allen is associated with self-deprecating humor, usually linked with his Jewish identity. However, in this movie he moves away from those themes and instead offers a plot that is not only humorous but deals with themes that can resonate with any audience. The story shows what how people can make a lot of half-baked decisions when their thinking is muddled. These decisions can cause a lot of damage and destroy friendships. For instance, Allen lauds the island of Manhattan while at the same time including scene after scene of a city that is grimy, dark, foreboding, and unfriendly, evidence of the kind of conflictual perceptions that mark the thinking of all of the characters. Filming the movie in black and white adds to the sense of emotional disconnection; there is simply nothing beautiful or charming about the city. The panoramic vistas are impressive but cold and foreboding, yet this is the venue where all the characters function. This movie contains what is probably Diane Keaton's greatest performance. She is clearly the star of the movie. If anyone has any doubt as to her talent as an actress, this movie will dispel those doubts. In this movie, Woody Allen is attempting to make a statement about the human condition and succeeds. This movie shows that people can hurt one another without meaning to do so and that the quest for personal happiness is a difficult road.

Woody Allen plays a divorced writer Isaac Davis who is going out with a 17 year old high school student Tracy (Mariel Hemmingway).His best friend is Yale (Michael Murphy), who is happily married but still finds an other love.Isaac falls for Yale's mistress Mary (Diane Keaton) and makes his life more problematic.Also his ex-wife makes it that by writing a book about their marriage.So it's not easy for this neurotic Jewish New Yorkian.Woody Allen's Manhattan (1979) has some dialogue that is funny, witty and bright.You won't hear this anywhere else than in Woody Allen's movie.And that smooth George Gershwin's music...This is some classy stuff.And it was made black and white, which gives a nice touch to the movie, I would say.Watch this movie.Listen to this movie.Maybe even love this movie if you don't find a love affair with a movie too weird.

reviews.review_title: Woody Allen's views the setting and mindset of Manhattan
reviews.content: With its Gershwin music and skyline cinematography, Manhattan strives to be the iconic New York City movie. I found the effort somewhat strained but I did like the views of Manhattan at night and the drive along Riverside Drive with the Upper West Side glowing in the background. Beyond the striking visual impressions, we have another Woody Allen take on the trials and tribulations of people, as they move in and out of relationships. This movie was written by Allen and shows his usual sardonic sense of humor as he portrays Isaac Davis, whose ex-wife Jill (Meryl Streep) has ''left me for another woman", as he puts it. This situation leaves Isaac even more humiliated. The male-baiting gives the movie some extra spark, particularly the hilarious accusation about Isaac's trying to run down Jill's new partner. Then there is Jill's pending book about their failed marriage, including their sex life, which he believes all his friends will be reading. The break-up is made worse by his loss of the custody of his child, who will now have to deal with two mothers, when one is enough of an albatross, as he puts it. Into the void, Isaac has struck up a serious friendship with a teenager named Tracy (Mariel Hemingway), who is twenty- five years younger. Mariel Hemingway is the essence of teenage innocence in this film and while we know she is much too young, we see her as a fragile presence who has helped Isaac get through the rough spots. He moves on to another woman named Mary (Diane Keaton) who has been abandoned by his friend Yale (Michael Murphy) who decides to go back to his wife. This leads to the awkward but funny situation of the two couples double-dating. Then Yale and Mary get back together again. Woody Allen has left us with a movie that has as much heart as humor. At the end of the movie, he feels he has found a grain of truth and moves on.

reviews.review_title: "You should think of me as sort of a detour in the highway of life."
reviews.content: I'm always a bit conflicted watching a Woody Allen movie. The guy can be brilliant, but always in the back of my mind is the way he betrayed a long time relationship with Mia Farrow by taking up with her adopted daughter Soon-Yi Previn. There was also the scandal revolving around adopted son Dylan Farrow, all of which makes me sour on Allen as a human being. It appears that in his early directed films, he might have offered some prophetic insight toward his behavior. For example, in "Bananas" there's a scene at a magazine stand where he's looking at a girlie mag, and he says to a bystander that he's doing a study on perversion and child molesting. Or take "Hannah and Her Sisters" where Allen's character blows off child molesting by saying that 'half the country is doing it'. So here, in "Manhattan", he's actually cavorting with a seventeen year old girlfriend portrayed by Mariel Hemingway, who oddly, turns out to be the most mature person out of all of Isaac's (Allen) acquaintances by the time the movie is over.Cinematically, I liked the film for it's crisp black and white portrayal of New York City, especially the night time scenes of distant cityscapes and beautifully lit street venues. As is often found in Allen's scripts, the characters deliver many of the nuances of love and life's miseries along with it's unintended consequences. Appearing as Isaac's ex-wife Jill, Meryl Streep probably never looked better on screen. But oh, those outfits and hair-do on Diane Keaton, those were the dictionary definition of dated if I had to come up with one. Not that any of the other players didn't evince the Seventies in their appearance, but Keaton's Mary certainly stood out.As for Woody Allen himself, he delivers the ultimate nebbish persona here that he made classically famous in his movies, stand-up routine and television guest spots. He really does come across as a funny guy, and charming enough in his own way, but it's tough to disassociate from one's own personal history. Try as I might, that dichotomy will always exist for me watching a Woody Allen picture.
The most beautiful portrayal of New York I have ever seen committed to screen. Allen's photography is pitch-perfect.

This movie sets a darker tone from Allen's usual humourous films.  I must admit, I love the music choices, and the idea of filming it black and white, but I find this movie lacking.  In the beginning of the film you get the impression that Allen's Isaac does not love Tracy, and wants to end their relationship.  Things pick up when he is matched with Keaton's Mary but that relationship goes sour.  Instead of dating Mary, he ends up hating his best friend.  Then after all that turmoil, he decides that he really did love Tracy and that he wants to be with her again.  if you like Allen's usual movies, I expect you'll enjoy this one.  I enjoyed parts of it but could still not grasp it as a whole.  It is simple, casual and similar to Allen's usual films.

When someone asks you what is this movie about you just answer them it's Woody Allen's movie and they will probably understand. His style of dialogue is so unique and perfect that you can learn a lot from them. He talks about all things from love to Kafka. Manhattan is just an example that Woody Allen did great movies in 70's and that his career isn't over yet.

In this movie, Wordy Allen makes love to George Gershwin, New York City, Diane Keaton, and an underage girl. Never all in the same scene, though. It was only 1979 after all, and the world hadn't yet been freed by the sexual revolution of the 1990s Mickey Mouse Club cast.I like the parts where Wordy stammers and fumbles around the set, making random references to philosophers and authors that most people have never read. It makes me feel like a genius when he mentions Kierkegaard or Kafka and I can say "I get that!" None of my friends ever want to talk about existential despair, so when I pop one of ol' Wordy's movies in, it feels like spending time with the friend I always wanted.. the friend I always deserved.. not like the stupid ones I actually ended up with.Plus, it was filmed in black and white, so you know right away that it's good!

reviews.review_title: Manhatttan-What's new in the outer boroughs? **1/2
reviews.content: Woody Allen uses the beautiful George Gershwin music to express his constant themes of intellectual nonsense, love-relationships and everything else in the milieu in 1979's "Manhattan."There is just too much going on here in the romantic skyline of things. Woody has twice been divorced and has one son from his marriage to Meryl Streep. Streep has written a book about their marriage and Woody tries to explore the lesbian world as she has left him for another woman.Mariel Hemingway, who received an Oscar nomination for best supporting actress in the film, is churlish and so immature by the nature of her speaking inflections, that she is a real standout here. Even when she turns the tables on Woody at the end, turning 18 has done nothing for this emotionally challenged young lady.Of course, Woody had to put in his controversial line that by quitting his job, he can't afford to pay for his father's expensive seat in the synagogue for the High Holidays and that the latter will have to sit in the rear. This was totally out of line.Diane Keaton does a very good job here because once again she plays that intellectual snob, full of herself, and in reality devoid of being able to maintain any meaningful relationship. I just loved when she said that she was married to her teacher and that "imagine, they went to bed and he gave her an F." This is good writing by Marshall Brickman.Woody's characters all follow the line of intellectual beings trying to find a place in the world, but they're so neurotic, it becomes impossible for them to achieve this. That's what's basically wrong with the film. Neurotic desires are still unfulfilled at film's end.

"Chapter One. He was as tough and romantic as the city he loved. Beneath his black-rimmed glasses was the coiled sexual power of a jungle cat. I love this. New York was his town, and it always would be..." The first time I saw Woody Allen's Manhattan I knew it was a special film. I mulled it over for a week or two, didn't rush it, let it's sensibilities soak in slowly, and then went back for a second viewing. It knocked me out. I thought it might be a perfect movie, which is not to say the greatest movie ever made (if there can be such a thing) but a perfect movie given the relationships between the elements that make up a film, in this case, the Gershwin score, the slightly overexposed b&w photography, the multi-layered script, the actors organised in a true ensemble, the direction and editing with Allen at his most confident. This is no mean feat. I cannot think of a single casting change I'd make, there is nary a false note in the entire piece. Allen, Keaton, Streep, Murphy, all brought their 'A' game but Hemingway is transcendent. She is an absolute revelation and the relationship with the Allen character rings true in every scene. New York never looked better, Gershwin never sounded better, Gordon Willis never exposed film better. This is what can happen when a singular talent holds all the cards and knows how to play them. Over the years, I've only lowered my opinion of this film very slightly. For me this ranks with City Lights.Woody/Issac musing about life, "Why is life worth living? It's a very good question. Um... Well, There are certain things I guess that make it worthwhile. uh... Like what... okay... um... For me, uh... ooh... I would say... what, Groucho Marx, to name one thing... uh... um... and Wilie Mays... and um... the 2nd movement of the Jupiter Symphony... and um... Louis Armstrong, recording of Potato Head Blues... um... Swedish movies, naturally... Sentimental Education by Flaubert... uh... Marlon Brando, Frank Sinatra... um... those incredible Apples and Pears by Cezanne... uh... the crabs at Sam Wo's... uh... Tracy's face..." I've never ordered crab at Sam Wo's and if I've ever heard Louis Armstrong playing Potato Head Blues, I didn't realise it, but I've seen a nearly perfect movie and, somehow, that also makes life worth living.

Woody Allen is very talented for what he is, but I'm not much of a fan of his films. Annie Hall was alright but nothing to write home about. For some reason and out of curiosity, I decided to borrow another one of his films. Big mistake. Manhattan ended up being a snooze fest. I suspect the high ratings came from those who are die-hard Woody fans.Manhattan seemed pointless. Even though it was only a ninety minute film, I couldn't couldn't finish. This film was basically about Woody Allen and his flirtations with women in his hometown of New York city. It is filmed in black and white and much of the shots are Woody and his date yapping along constantly to no end. Unless you are a fan of him, skip this Manhattan.

reviews.review_title: New York in black and white...Very Romantic
reviews.content: If there's one Woody Allen to see (besides Hannah and Her Sisters [Allen's best]), see this movie. Listen for Diane Keaton's pronunciation of 'Van Gogh' in the first half hour, a view of the old Hayden planetarium (Woody and Diane in silhouette), and that great scene of Diane and Woody at dawn at the dead end of 57th Street in the shadow of the 59th Street Bridge. The opening credits are wonderful scenes of the city, especially the views over Central Park. Why does Woody ditch cute little Mariel for the troubled and troubling Diane, and why is he friends with that selfish egocentricMichael Murphy? That's why New Yorkers are too wrapped up in themselves, and its fun to see ourselves on the screen. And oh yeah, great music too!

This is going against not only all the critics, but every other comment here. I thought that "Manhattan" was overrated. This is just my opinion. I'd say that with all the other people in the world liking it, it's probably still a good movie and I'm just a jack@$$. But let me at least tell you why I didn't like it:1. This was supposed to be a comedy. It was on the AFI's 100 Funniest Movies List. But I didn't think it was funny at all.2. The photography was awful. Most of the time it was just two people walking down the street, talking. Then it was just two people sitting at a bar, talking. Sometimes they were even talking under a plain black screen. You can close your eyes and still get the full effect of this movie.3. It doesn't surprise me that in a film that Woody Allen wrote, directed, and starred in, he writes himself in a relationship with two women.Well, at the risk of getting a life sentence from the IMDB court, I think I'll stop now. You should probably still rent this movie if you're thinking about it, but help me out here if you agree with me. Write a comment.

reviews.review_title: The Prophet of the Pathetically Maladjusted
reviews.content: The Prophet of the neurotic, urban, introspective intelligentsia is once again both narcissistic and self-deprecating which is the long-lived charm of the Woody Allen mystique.Here the backdrop is his beloved city. His and others ever unsatisfied love and sex life is the pulse. The palpitations are presented here with the usual jittery psychology and philosophy, with the obligatory jabs at religion and the Nazis, and the good, but not great, script is helped, once again, by good supporting actors.There are a lot more laughs in his other films and the drama is sometimes a little too unsettling to be either amusing or easily approached, especially the generational gyrations, even though it is the love of his life. That he is sincere is not enough to endear any attachment to the character and one could think that in this case Woody has looked deeper, than need be, into the mirror.

reviews.review_title: A rather sad Woody Allen on the stage of an enchanting New York
reviews.content: The opening frame of Manhattan skyline on Gershwin's "Rhapsody in blue" is simply enchanting, I think the best and most emotionally involving cinematographic shot of New York I have ever seen, you perceive that the director is in love with this magic city. "Manhattan" by Woody Allen comes two years after "Annie Hall": same setting, same neurotic protagonist, same intellectual commitment, but different mood. I must admit that I did not know much about Allen's earlier production and it was "Whatever works" to instill a desire in me to rediscover some classics I had seen when I was probably too young to understand them, and I can now say that I was positively surprised by the subtlety and modernity of Allen's view. "Annie Hall" was more funny, the neurotic character of Alvy Singer was sometimes annoying, but also amusing and tenderly looking for love. Here we find Isaac, a middle-aged man, looking for something, for anything, but incapable of filling the void of his complicated world. He acts on the stage of a city, which has become the symbol of a whole "degenerated generation", having lost all moral sense, the metaphor of a lost world, made of intellectually brilliant, but extremely superficial men and women, shifting from one bed to another without distinguishing between sex and love, simply because not interested in the distinction and where intellectualism cannot save them when facing the "real thing" of life.I think if we see the movie as a tribute to the out of time glamour of New York, we can consider it an incomparable milestone in the history of cinematography, if we get into moral and human reflection, we get a very sad and depressing view of human alienation. In the end we either pity or blame this lost man, but the overall atmosphere is rather melancholic and humanly depressing, and even Isaac's sometimes annoying talkativeness and mannerism can be forgiven. For me, pity prevailed over blame. As I have already said when reviewing "Annie Hall", as compared to the recent "Whatever works", Allen's latest movie reveals a more compliant willingness to accept the good of life, which in the end disregards too many complications of his younger years. In "Manhattan" we go back to thirty years ago, and, obviously, no sort of this serene acceptance is to be found, here the search for life is still in hard progress, and no well-wrapped happy ending is in sight.

This movie fires on so many cylinders that it takes multiple viewings to appreciate all that Woody had to say. My first screening was in the theater in 1979. I was captivated by the stunning B&W cinematography and the splendid Gershwin music. With subsequent viewings I focused more on the dialogue and performances. As with most Woody films, the casting is brilliant. Hemingway is the standout -I can't imagine anyone else in that part. She conveys vulnerability and sophistication all at once. A masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: woody loves a city with more ease than he loves a woman
reviews.content: Manhattan, the actual city itself, is shot beautifully here because it's seen thru the eyes of someone who is hopelessly in love with it. There's no crime here, no real noise, no violence. Maybe a wry comment on how hard it is to find a parking space. That's about it. It's all filtered thru an optimistic lens, even as the characters drive each other nuts with indecision and selfish behavior. It's because the characters DON'T have to confront crime, poverty or violence, that they're left pretty much dealing with their screwed up emotions. The big irony here is that Mariel Hemingway's 17 year old Tracy is the most mature main character in the story. The grown ups all act like adolescents. The real adolescent is the more stable of the bunch. Funny stuff... Comments have already been made on how nice the picture looks. It's almost crisp. Like a fall afternoon. But lacking the color of a fall day. Maybe the only true way to capture the scenery? Great cast, as always, in every Woody piece. Seamless acting. Fine writing. Well chosen music. And humor that sneaks up on you. It never grows old...

The opening shots of MIDNIGHT IN Paris (2011, 6/10) can easily hack back to this Black & White paean to New York made more than three decades age, with the same deployment of representative landmarks (although I have yet set my foot on America). The storyline may suit perfectly as a prophesy for Allen his own private life decades later, to which I am trying my best shun away since the independence of the film should be irrelevant of the creator's personal idiosyncrasy, which is a hard call in this case. It's a petit bourgeois melodrama, could be a sequel of ANNE HALL (1977, 9/10), there is still Allen and Keaton, and Allen is still a neurotic and nagging cipher, but Keaton here is not a winning scatterbrain, instead being characterized as a high-strung lost cause, which in a sense, these two are very much alike, pretending sophisticate as a charade to conceal their immature rationality. Words are Allen's strongest weapon, so albeit being a bit piqued by the characters (pretentiousness, stupidity and high-brow condescending), the script itself has its shrewdness and comedic tones will suffice to launch an ambiguous attachment towards our commonplace life. The "humungous" ex-husband Jeremiah (a cameo by Wallace Shawn) is a caustically satirical prank to highlight the core of self-deception and all the hogwash people brag everyday. This film should also be conceived as a tribute to silent masterpieces (Chaplin's work maybe), the George Gershwin strains are a true rhapsody for fanboys. Visually there are great silhouettes when Allen and Keaton are together, most noteworthy is when they are conversing against the artificial starry night in the museum (which along with the ex-wife's lesbian family, I may detect some references which would later appear in the magnate soap opera FRIENDS). I am a bit bemused to find out Mariel Hemingway has procured an Oscar nomination because she barely has any juicy presentation apart from one heart-breaking segment, but if one must pick someone to grant the appreciation, Hemingway is the best choice since she is the only lovable character in the film. Allen and Keaton can not surpass ANNE HALL which is only two years earlier (although no one looks better than Keaton in the trouser-and-stiletto combo). Michael Murphy, if not the weakest linkage in the midst, is a quite lame professor, unabashedly self-centred scumbag. Streep, only has three major scenes as the dashing lesbian ex-wife, which are all setting against a perpetually occupied motion.

Midnight In Paris takes its opening from Manhattan, and both are loving odes to great cities, but here additionally we have the smooth jazz saxophone of Gershin, and the voice-over of a certain neurotic trying to find the perfect opening lines to his book. There are some truths and some lies. The biggest truth is Isaac's love for the city, something that even passing time cannot erode - he intends to immortalise it in Willis' stunning black and white photography that captures a distant past, a nostalgic version of the skyscrapers, the ferries, the butcheries, the snowy parks, and of course the iconic shot of the Queensboro Bridge twinkling and silhouetting what seems to be a lovestruck pair. And then he is exaggerating in some instances; he maintains that he and will still have the coiled sexual power of a jungle cat even in his 70s, and remarks if there is anyone that he models himself after it is god.
