However when it comes time to break up with the 17 year-old Tracy, he subtly deflects the doe-eyed interrogation of love into an act for her own good - now he is 42, miserable, and his hair is falling out. He is self-righteous, but not on the same level of pretentiousness as Yale or Mary, who pride themselves in their 'Academy of Overrated' and disparage great artists from all areas. Watch how they and Isaac spar - well not spar, they laugh and snicker, while Isaac adamantly refuses their every suggestion. But one line from his ex-wife's memoir of their disastrous marriage seems to suggest he is not so different (and the group laugh out loud at this reading, but as ElMaruecan82 points out, Tracy would never have done so, and I agree); as much as he seems to despise these pseudo-intellectual New Yorkers, he chases eagerly after one and only succeeds in doing so on account of being one himself. He is disillusioned with his successful comedy show, so he quits without really thinking just how much of a downgrade he will have to suffer in his lifestyle - what is more important, his integrity, or the colour of his tap water? He complains at length about it, and in the next scene the cameras tracks him as he walks over to hand a crystal clear glass of water to Mary, but we already knew that it was her. He adjusts his personality depending on who he is trying to woo. He is also hypocritical. Watch how two grown men argue and bicker over a grown women like she is a toy. Yale spits out that he saw her first. Isaac is clearly bitter about being cheated on despite doing the same to Tracy. Yale childishly retaliates later and lies to his wife, solely pushing the blame on his dear friend. Earlier, they unexpectedly bump into Mary's ex-husband, and Isaac is pushed swiftly out of the frame, but it matters not, because Wallace Shawn as Jeremiah is his spitting image, middle-aged, balding, short (it's even suggested he used to be overweight). Isaac marvels that a man that looks like that could ever be a dominating, devastating sexual partner - but of course, he's assigned these roles to himself.Mariel Hemingway is Tracy, the 17 year old girlfriend, and hers is perhaps the best performance of them of all, quiet, assured, straight faced. It is a testament to her ability that I find myself with troubling thoughts, never once wondering about her attraction to the older Isaac, but questioning over and over how he managed to get her. This is the mindset of Isaac, who manages to convince himself and her that she is youthful beyond her pretty face, that she is inexperienced and precocious, that she has many lovers ahead, and that she does not yet know what love is. In short, that she is uncorrupted. Watch his little sly smile as Tracy answers "I go to high school", clearly out of her element, and he loves this about her. He is babying her, but indulging in it at the same time. Willis frames the two close yet far apart in the stylish apartment, distant, as he once again lectures her on how to approach this relationship that seems a dying cause. She makes a joke about how little he thinks of her knowledge of the arts, and we cut away before he can respond, but we know it is a dismissive one. They take a horse drawn carriage through the glittering nightime skyline, and Isaac dubs the experience corny, saying he's done it all before as a kid, but deep down he treasures this little memory, and thinks himself lucky to be able to do it again with such a beautiful girl. He finally comes to his senses in the final scene. Once again we start with a voice-over, which quickly turns into something more immediate and genuine - he is not attempting to wittily open his biography, but quietly recording himself musing over life's wonders. Music (most of all Gershin, who serenades throughout), cinema, good food, and then he fixates on Tracy's face. He runs her down, perhaps one of the first instances of this romantic comedy type confession. But here, although it is sincere (the most he has been the entire movie), it is also selfish, and he is sabotaging all his previous arguments and insistence on her naivety and youthfulness and boundless opportunities, but if he can have her again, it does not matter. He pleads for her to not get corrupted, while she insists it is just a few months. Who is the kid here?

reviews.review_title: On of the very best American films of the 1970s
reviews.content: This wonderful film continues to amaze after repeat viewings.  I had the pleasure of seeing this in the theater when it first came out and have probably seen it four or five times since and am still in awe of it.  The tribute to Manhattan, the glorious black-and-white cinematography by Gordon Willis, the Gershwin soundtrack, the clever and funny dialogue by Woody Allen and Marshall Brickman, and the acting by Allen, Keaton, Hemingway, and Streep make this one of the very best American films of the 1970s.  Keaton is luminous, funny, and touching.  Her 'I'm from Philadelphia' routine is so funny.  The scene at the planetarium and the shot of Allen and Keaton sitting on the park bench with the Brooklyn Bridge in the background at dawn are breathtaking.  This is just one in a long string of Allen's films, featuring Keaton, which made them national treaures.

reviews.review_title: As If Woody Allen Couldn't Get More Awkward...
reviews.content: As if Woody Allen couldn't get more awkward...he writes a film where he dates a beautiful 17 year old actress.Only to ditch her for his best friends mistress...who he actually loathes.Only for her to ditch him, to go back to his best friend, who leaves his very nice wife for her.Leaving Allen with only one choice...to go back to his 17 year old vixen...who is just about to leave for London to study music and acting.I hate to admit it- especially in light of the whole Allen vs Farrow fiasco- but from his perspective- (and i cringe when I write this) but from his perspective...this is very much the right choice.He was clearly much happier with her, despite the fact that he is disgustingly loathsome, himself.Which is probably why he ended it in the first place- in order to date someone he considered very much equally loathsome.Because she is a reflection of what he considered himself, and felt he very much deserved.Instead of continuing to taint an otherwise perfectly respectable Goddess, played by the lovely and innocent Mariel Hemingway.Cringe factor aside...the whole thing is shot in black & white, and set to the Broadway music of George Gershwin...which is really quite an apt setting for the whole drab affair (sorry George).There's nothing about Woody Allen, that comes off to me, as witty or alluring.So I just don't get it.But I do love the time capsulesque shots of vintage New York City.And Allen does have his moments of poeticism.So...I guess he's not completely void of anything worthy of cultural value.But his films just don't do much for me otherwise.It is what it is.5.5 out of 10.

I've never seen so many mixed user comments for any movie like I see for "Manhattan".  When I first saw it back in 1986, Woody Allen was at his "height" again after "Hannah and Her Sisters".  So I watched it with a sense of awe then.  Now, 17 years later, I sat through "Manhattan" again and I have to say that I generally agree with the people here that say it's overrated.  After so many years of seeing Woody Allen's films, there is a repetitiveness in so many of his themes: death, meaning of life (or lack of..) and infidelity.  Jesus, he even managed to get those themes into "Radio Days".  Even his dialogue sounds the same from movie to movie and it really bothers me now.  The film is beautiful to look at sometimes but that is because he used Gordon Willis as his Director of Photography.  That man could make anything look great and here he does.  He even shoots scenes of garbage piled up on the streets and it looks OK.  The main problem with "Manhattan" and similar movies like "Hannah and Her Sisters" is that when all is said and done, why should we really care about any of these people? I'm not expecting Allen to do a movie about welfare mothers or drug addicts in New York but these people are priviledged, spoiled white people who whine about death and how their relationships go no where.  After all these years, his movies have become pointless and stifling.  I still like "Crimes and Misdemeanors" and "Bananas", "Sleeper" and "Annie Hall".  But the guy thinks WAY too much of himself and his "ideas".  The word now for Mr. Allen is insufferable.  It's too bad.  There was a time when he was truly dynamic. Now he's irrelevant.  Skip this movie unless you're a big Woody Allen fan and "need" to see all his work.

This is Woody Allen's best film followed by HANNAH & HER SISTERS and ANNIE HALL. Gorgeous black/white cinematography, great music (Gershwin), and splendid performances. Mariel Hemingway should have won Supporting Actress for her intelligent and sensitive teenager dating Allen. Michael Murphy is the perfect yuppie (who can't decide whether to write his novel or buy a Porsche). It's also one of Woody's best acting characterizations and the film ends brilliantly.A 9 out of 10. Best performance = Ms. Hemingway. One of Allen's best scripts (humane, funny, and insightful). This should have received the awards ANNIE HALL received and I don't understand why it didn't.HUSBAND & WIVES and STARDUST MEMORIES are other great ones from The Woodman.

reviews.review_title: Woody Allen's love/hate-letter to the City of His Soul.
reviews.content: Woody Allen is easily one of the most brilliant satire-directors of cinema, and 1979's 'Manhattan' is one of his grandest achievements. Woody Allen stars as Isaac Davis, a TV-writer who's uncomfortable with his job and his 17-year old girlfriend Tracy - so instead he starts off writing a novel and becomes besotted with Mary, a neurotic intellectual who's having an affair with Isaac's best friend, Yale. Woody Allen more or less plays himself in another round of wit and self-deprecation, Diane Keaton who feels misplaced and uncomfortable about dating a married man, Mariel Hemingway as the beautiful and innocent drama student and off course the young Meryl Streep, Isaac's ex-wife who left him for another woman.The psychoanalysis of 'Manhattan' is pure Woody Allen, and he keeps his wit and charm in top-form. But most memorable of all is its starry depiction of Manhattan, photographed in gorgeous black-and-white by Gordon Willis - the opening montage is like a Valentin-letter to the city of his soul, city-pictures with Allen's narrative-voice is possibly Allen's greatest opening scene ever. The production design speaks just as loudly as the characters does, and wherein they speak it's dry wit, neo-intellectuality or emotions a-flow - and therefore it's particularly memorable towards the ending, as Isaac lays on his couch recording his thoughts on the citizens of Manhattan's many neurosis, on the way that keeps them away from confronting bigger and more unsolvable problems - he cheers himself (and the audience) up by listing things that does life worth living; whether it's Groucho Marx, sports, films or literature.'Manhattan' is Manhattan with romanticism and wit; the beautiful, moody takes of Allen and Keaton benched below 52nd Street Bridge is one of cinema's most memorable and the blending use of George Gershwin-music really puts it all at ease, and in one notable scene we cut right from Allen and Hemingway's sweet park-date with loud music to the reality of Mary and Yale fighting over their secret relationship.Woody Allen gives us a tour of his Manhattan, the gorgeous and magical aspects of it, but also the bitterness and neurotic nature of himself and itself. And the way Allen contributed his natural humor into the urban-romance-drama is magnificent, and it's really one of the most notable romance-comedies of all time, and is truly a standout.

"Manhattan" is a romantic comedy movie in which we watch a man who is a divorced television writer and he is dating a teenage girl, getting into a strange and complicated situation. This situation is an erotic triangle in which he fells in love with his best friend's mistress. In addition to this we have plenty of more information about his ex-wife, his job and how this influences his relationships and his character.It's a classic Woody Allen movie in which we have romance, many erotic conversations, a lot of scenes of the beautiful Manhattan and of course a nice direction made by Woody Allen. I liked the interpretation of Woody Allen who played as Isaac and I have to say that he was really good at it. Another interpretation that has to be mentioned is the beautiful Diane Keaton's who played as Mary and she was equally good.Lastly I believe that "Manhattan" is not the best movie of Woody Allen but is still interesting to watch and if you have a spare time this is a nice choice. I also have to say that this movie shows very well how a person changes when some situations come in his life and he did not expect them, and how he deals with them.

This is the cinematic equivalent of a pond skater: never piercing the surface, just fidgeting around in aimless panicked superficiality.  The film has no depth; the characters are pointless non-serious no-bodies; the pseudo-intellectualising has no moral / psychological direction and no foundation in knowledge (Keats's phrase negative capability' is misused twice without any allusion to the poet).  The only serious person is the seventeen year old girl who is dismissed as a stupid kid with a Mickey mouse voice: when presented with the profound talent and a wise fidelity of Mariel Hemingway's character this is all the film can come up with.  The reason why the film and Woody Allen have been so successful is because they never compete against anything above their own very low level.  The film is full of people each of them more pathetic or superficial than the next, so that it is hard to realise that they are all such a waste of time  each of them justifying the other's lack of values.  The same can be said of Woody Allen: there is no one else in the history of cinema who has had so little ability, but so high an opinion of himself; he stands alone because he is the only person with such an extraordinarily mediocre vision to dare to reach so high; to project his nothingness no relentlessly. The film is only great as far as Mariel Hemingway is great: she is great and she has the last word ergo the film is great.  She carries the whole film through and tops it off, despite Allen's inability to work himself up to any profound emotional state for the finale (even with the strenuous running).

Anyone who has not seen a Woody Allen film, but enjoys film in general, should watch Manhattan. It is brilliantly filmed, romantic, and very funny. A person who loves New York city (Manhattan), and has only heard of Woody Allen in a bathroom conversation, should rent "Manhattan" NOW! Aside from "Annie Hall", this is Allen's best work in an overall evaluation. The excellent cinematography is all about New York, and these interesting characters who live in the City. There isn't really a plot to the film. It is about people's lives, and how much Allen loves the City. great ensemble performances by Allen, Keaton, and especially Mariel Hemingway as the sensitive, youthful love of the protagonist. It actually warms my heart to watch the letterboxed version, everytime, because of the humour and passion in the film is timeless. "Manhattan" is great entertainment, and a heart-felt work by a master of American film. "Manhattan" is timeless.

Review: This movie is definitely a tribute to New York City. The scenery looks great throughout the film and the black and white theme, really does work. As for the movie itself, it just seemed like your typical Woody Allen movie, which are usually about relationships between friends and lovers. For 1979, this must have been a unique movie because of its mixture between comedy and serious relationship issues, which we all can relate to, but for this day and age, we have seen this type of film many times before. The relationship between Woody and the young girl was interesting, along with the ex-wife, played by Meryl Streep, whose become a lesbian after having a child with Woody, so there's enough material to keep the movie watchable. Personally, it does go down as some of his best work because he got everything right, but I'm still struggling to get his humour. Watchable!Round-Up: After watching some of Woody Allen's later work, I can see why everyone rated his earlier on projects because he had a unique style of directing/writing which is very dry and offensive but in a joking type of way. Half of his jokes in his earlier movies, wouldn't be politically correct for modern times, which is why it's easier to stick with Romantic Comedies. Anyway, Mariel Hemingway put it a emotional and realistic performance, at such a young age, and the rest of the cast made the movie believable interesting.Budget: $9million Worldwide Gross: $40millionI recommend this movie to people who are into there Woody Allen movies about finding love and relationships with close friends. 6/10

reviews.review_title: All about discovering what love is in the Big Apple
reviews.content: There's really nothing profound in "Manhattan," Woody Allen's first success after 1977's "Annie Hall." It's a story about trying to find what relationships work best that is merely themed in New York City. You get a sense that this movie was Allen really trying to do a film that he wanted to do while using some of the same tactics from "Annie Hall." But while Allen tries to give the film a classic feel by showing shots of the city and the skyline, filming in black and white and using Gershwin music throughout, it's really a movie more about people and their often strange relationships.Allen plays another moderately successful Jewish writer named Isaac Davis trying to live in New York City who has been married twice, has a child and in comic Allen fashion his last wife (interestingly enough played by Meryl Streep) left him and became a lesbian. Now of course, at the age of 42, he's dating a 17-year-old (Mariel Hemingway). If that weren't enough his best friend Yale (Murphy) is having an affair with a woman (Keaton) who Isaac can't help but also be interested in.The film is about these characters and how they handle each other and their views of themselves. Both Allen and Keaton's characters are much different from "Annie Hall," mostly because they aren't as likable because they're egotistical. Allen believes he's a sex maniac and Keaton believes she's a highly intellectual, beautiful young woman when she's really just pretentious. The acting is great and the characters are definitely interesting, but certainly not lovable. If you really take the time to analyze the characters there is a lot of depth to the film. Allen is sure to use a wide array of troubled relationships, especially by contrasting Isaac with Tracy (the high schooler). At the same time, however, there really isn't much of a dramatic climax and you spend too much time picking the characters apart because of their glaring flaws to really care about what's happening to them.Perhaps Allen's biggest fault here is not really working in New York City like the film title and the film's opening suggest. You want to feel like the city should be its own character but it never quite gets there. There is some suggestion about the city as a place of comfort, and Allen chooses many interesting shot angles that include the background more than usual, but you don't feel that being in New York adds a significant layer to the film.Overall, "Manhattan" is a terrific film about relationships and having difficulty in them. There is a lot of painful truth in the way these characters view and deal with their lives and view and deal with each other. If only Allen took more time to get the film to really hit on some of those moments and make them echo stronger, "Manhattan" would have been more than just a classic to the Allen-loving crowd.

I've seen only a handful of Allen's films and found them very enjoyable, but I've not seen any of the real "classics" from his work. So after hearing so many good things about this movie, I decided to rent the DVD.I know I'm in the minority here, but I was letdown by the film. There were parts that were brilliant, but I found most of the characters to be very weak. I didn't care about them at almost any point in the film.It started with Allen's Issac. I found the relationship with Hemingway's Tracy to be appalling. Basically, we're supposed to root for a guy who is committing statutory rape throughout the film. I'm no prude, but I just couldn't stand the sight of them togther -- it was repulsive to me. Allen's dilemma over the relationship worked for a while, but his ultimate decision over Tracy bothered me.Second, Issac doesn't really seem to grow in the film. He starts out as self-centered and self-righteous and doesn't really change at all. It's only through his self-centeredness (listing the things that make HIS life worth living) that he realizes he wants Tracy.Yale was a decent character -- his constant rationalizations were a sharp commentary on modern morals. But his wife was completely two-dimensional. It seemed as if Allen didn't know what to do with her.Likewise, Meryl Streep as Issac's former wife was also underdeveloped. Streep looked tired and delivered her lines with no conviction.On the other hand, I liked Diane Keaton's neurotic character. She started off as this obnoxious pseudo-intellectual, but Keaton did a great job showing her vulnerable side and her inability to make herself happy. She was the one person who seemed real to me in the film.There is some brilliant dialog (Issac and Yale's argument at the end, Issac's criticism of borgeouis intellectuallism) and I loved the camera work. I used to live in NYC, and seeing this film made me want to go back. But when a movie so character-driven has characters so creatively bankrupt, it's hard to enjoy it.

reviews.review_title: I Want to Like This Movie
reviews.content: And that's why I am giving it a 6 instead of a 4. I've read dozens of reviews of Manhattan, trying to understand what people love about it. Each and every review praises the romance brought to screen. There must be something wrong with me because I didn't find this movie romantic at all. It seemed like a string of narcissistic flings more than any true romances. Not one character was the least bit appealing, except maybe for Tracy, if only for her sincerity. I thought Issac was a complete louse, and not because of the age difference; he just seemed selfish, flippant, and needy. He did have some good lines though, especially mocking the pseudo-intellectual art crowd, and the scene with the skeleton was pretty great. I thought Keaton was annoying, and Streep was pacing around way too much. Was she attached to a motor or something? Look, it's not that I need to have lovable characters. Scorsese has horrible characters but they serve the story, when the point is corruption, violence, what have you. But if the point is romance, then the characters should at least be tolerable. Not these neurotic rich white new yorkers! Maybe other ones in other Allen vehicles. The music was about a thousand decibels louder than the rest of the sound in the film, so that I was forced to keep adjusting the volume with the remote, even though I don't like altering the experience of a work. The photography is wonderful. Too bad the content underneath it is so banal. And I like banality! My favorite director is Robert Altman, for goodness sake. It didn't make sense to me that the film making was so artistic, yet what I was watching was so bland. It's like if Orson Wells shot Monster-in-law. Well, that might be an exaggeration. Anyhow, the style just didn't seem appropriate. Maybe it would have if I had felt the amazing romance. Or if I had seen this when I was going through my wistful New York phase. Alas, Manhattan is certainly not what it once was, too bad. Basically, I felt like this should have been my kind of movie but just wasn't at all, and there aren't enough negative words about it on the internet. That's why I have written this. I certainly wouldn't fault anyone for liking Manhattan, as I wouldn't fault anyone for liking your mom, it just misses the mark with me.

In general, this is "typical". Typical Allen humor with the actors playing typical roles. Which actually means it's good because there's real talent there.Other things are at work, however. First of all, we have the opening line about New York, the city that "exists in black and white and pulses to the sounds of Gershwin music." It's a really good image, but I think, unfortunately, that the black and white photography was a bit poor. Also, I, uh... don't really like Gershwin music. It's just kind of loud and obnoxious to me. Which fits New York, but not the nice imagery.This movie is apparently about "the fall of human values" or something to that effect. Can't say I got too much of that out of it, except that the relationships that pull together at the end are definitely more surprising than you'd think. We expect a different outcome, we're given a different one.This film is also interesting because it features Allen's character dating a high schooler. I'm not quite clear on the Allen timeline and where he is with his whole crazy relationships thing, so I don't know if this was made before or after he got together with his adopted daughter, but either way it's an interesting thing to put into a film considering the character.Allen also has the ability to make me burst out in laughter despite myself, even during times when I'm not sure I find it funny.All in all it has some good technique and is definitely enjoyable to Allen fans. However he's done better and I can't shake off the feeling that it's just too typical for its own good.--PolarisDiB

reviews.review_title: Hasn't stood the test of time
reviews.content: I've been back here 2 or 3 times over the years, revisited 'Manhattan' about once a decade, always trying to get it. But now convinced I never will. Possibly Allen's most self-indulgent work, it garnered multiple awards on the back of 'Annie Hall'; a bit like 'Tusk' after 'Rumours', everyone wanted it to be brilliant and rushed to celebrate it, but there was really very little there. One laugh-out-loud gag that I recall, otherwise tedious and questionable moral dilemmas of a man bordering on middle age implausibly targeted by a statuesque 17 year-old Candice Bergman. Wonder what she thinks about him now.

In the first films of Woody Allen ("Bananas" (1971) and "Sleeper" (1973)) he is still recognizable as a former stand up comedian. Not much later the somewhat neurotic Freud interpreter with fear of commitment in relationships would evolve as the typical main character in Allan films (often played by himself).A second constant factor in the career of Allan is his love for New York. Only later in his career his films would be situated in other city's such as London ("Matchpoint, 2005), Barcelona ("Vicky Cristina Barcelona", 2008) and Paris ("Midnight in Paris", 2011).These two element come together in films like "Annie Hall" (1977) and "Manhattan" (1979), his best films up to the present day. "Manhattan" is an ode to the city, and the city of New York certainly is one of the characters, if not the main character.Making films about a city is not a new idea. Examples from earlier days of film history are "Berlin, die Sinfonie der Grosstadt" (1927, Walther Ruttmann) and "Menschen am Sonntag" (1930, Robert Siodmak & Edgar Ulmer), both about Berlin.The fact is however that a declaration of love to the city of New York was not at all very logical in the seventies. The city was in decay and it took three capable mayors (Ed Koch, Rudolph Giuliani and Michael Bloomberg) to put the city back on track again. A film such as "Taxi driver" (1976, Martin Scorsese) gives a totally different picture of the city.Nevertheless, "Manhattan" is a declaration of love to the city of New York, and nowhere is this more obvious than in the brilliant opening scene.Beautiful images in black and white.Beautiful music in the form of "Rhapsody in blue" by George Gershwin.A chaatic monologue in which Isaac Davis (Woody Allen) is thinking about the opening lines of his novel about New York, but gets stuck al the time.The chaotic opening monologue made me think of the opening monologue in "The Big Lebowski" (1998, Joel & Ethan Coen).

Aesthetics - this is the word I would use to describe this film. Aesthetics in everything - in the visual composition, in the behavior of the characters, in witty dialogues, and in the very essence of the film. Even its minimalistic tones introduced with the help of black-and-white photography permeates this film with a romantic flourish. The actors' dialogues are filled with drollery and, at the same time, meaning, reflections on life, interpersonal relations, and self-discovery. That is not a typical comedy like "Friends", where comic situations and play on words in addition to behind-the-scenes laughter make the viewer laugh. With Woody Allen's comedy, it's just the opposite. The maximum realism of the story and the behavior of the characters, accurately combined with their rhetoric, create a kind of mirror for the viewer to self-observe and laugh. The humor in 'Manhattan' doesn't seem forced or written in just to make something funnier, the jokes are naturally funny.'Manhattan' narrates us the story of several characters that are going through several affairs: Isaac Davis (played by Woody Allen himself) who is twice-divorced and has an affair with a seventeen years old girl, and his best friend, Yale (Michael Murphy), who is married and has an affair with a girl he met at a party. The relationships aren't really the point of the movie though. It's more about what people say during relationships - how their words affect each other and shift each own perspective. I personally can single out the acting of Mariel Hemingway who plays that seventeen years old girl. Her character is so pure and innocent. Still unaffected by Manhattan values she believes that a person can have a one true love for the rest of his or her life. She has faith in people and represents a hope which other characters seem to have lost.No wonder this very film by Woody Allen has been selected for preservation in the National Film Registry. One important thing to note: movies that are selected there are not the best American films of all time, but rather considered as works of enduring importance to American culture. They reflect who Americans are as a people and as a nation. And 'Manhattan' is that movie. Woody Allen was born in New York, spent a lot of his time there, and by viewing this movie, you can certainly tell that he loves it, especially Manhattan. And it is his love of New York that drives the movie. It's his homage to the city, and the way he shows it to us, through cinematography, is the way he sees it, and it truly is fascinating. He doesn't hide from us its imperfections, that it is hectic, self-obsessed, and disturbing in some way. He shows us its real self - and that is valuable.New York is indeed a magical and alluring city. It is a muse for many people of artistic nature. One of them was Scott Fitzgerald, who also drew his inspiration from it. In his essay published in 1932 titled My Lost City, he describes his relationship with New York and his becoming its citizen. Although he was born in Minnesota, his susceptible yet conscious years were spent in New York thus, influencing him greatly and subsequently his creative work. Neither Scott Fitzgerald nor Woody Allen portrait New York as an idealistic city, but whereas for the former - it became dull like its spirit faded away, for the latter - it is still something sacred, something loved. For Fitzgerald, the young generation of that time, in his eyes, is lost. He writes in his essay: 'Young people wore out early - they were hard and languid at twenty-one... none of them contributed anything new.' For Allen - the young generation (in the guise of young Mariel Hemingway) is hopeful, striving for better.'Manhattan' is more than just a film - it is a tribute. It is a sign of love and respect that could not have been expressed by mere words. It is a piece of art created by a man who put in it a part of himself.

Manhattan is the only time in Woody Allens life where he sells out to the public. After Annie Hall, Woody was on top of the world with being the King of Comedy. A comedy genius, who had won Academy Awards for screen writing and best film, and who was nominated for best actor, went on the next year to write INTERIORS. The public didn't know how to react. No something a comic genius would do. The public asked Woody for another Annie Hall film and so he gave the world Manhattan. Sit back and think off all the things in common between Annie Hall and Manhattan. You'll find many things that the two films have in common.While Interiors prove Allen is a master of making films on relationships and family, Manhattan proves that Woody can make us laugh by feeding the public used plots and character structure. On second thought, Manhattan does have its moments. It's worth watching twice!

reviews.review_title: I'm Glad There's Only One Chapter
reviews.content: Chapter One, I'm filming a love note to you, New York City. No, too endearing and subservient. Let me start this over.Chapter One, I'm filming a story about you, New York City, the most beautiful town on earth. In fact I'll be in you throughout the filming. No, too erotic. Too sexual.Chapter One, New York City, I'm filming a tapestry of your many complexities and nuances, leaving no stone unturned, no filth free of its objective natural decay, no natural beauty free of its subjective essence. No, too psycho-analytical.Chapter One, I mean, what to say, really. New York City, I'm asking you to allow me to use you as a background character. Like anyone who wants to be in my films, whether good or bad, you'll pose stupidly, in black and white, a straight man to my self-indulgent rants. I'll star and chatter endlessly before, during, and after the lines delivered by the two dimensional, ridiculously unrealistic versions of human beings (and their analysts), beings who will become nothing more than foils to my massive ego disguised as a neurotic whine. At some point, I'll unwittingly or poignantly describe the noise I make as a trumpet sawed in half. I'll lecture characters and myself simultaneously as the cliched triangle-headed anti-hero in black frames, repeatedly questioning yet reaffirming the animal magnetism that somehow tractor beams a pretty girl in high school with homework and an allegedly insecure women who speaks her mind from the outset of the film but then crumbles before my domineering presence in bed. I'll have conquered other terrific beauties, one of which is raising my son with a lesbian partner I tried to run over (and writing a book about our relationship, probably mentioning what a dynamo I was in bed... perhaps? Yes?... Hopefully?... BUT I'M COMPLETELY AGAINST IT!). Speaking of triangles, my dry toast married best friend "Yale" will become the anti-hero to my anti-hero, as we both swing our way through the city having relations upon relations with these or other women. I'll struggle through the trials of multiple divorces, alimony, a young, over-sexed girl, and an insecure woman who both can and cannot live without me and the aforementioned married friend who is in love with her. I'll show off my virile athleticism, stumbling down a sidewalk as I dribble a basketball during visitation with my son, and later stumbling across a racquetball court during visitation with my best friend. I'll be built up into a god-like creature, before having to deal with the seemingly interminable fallout of too many women wanting to have sex with me at once. What a dilemma! Did I mention we'll talk about it this the whole film through, from scene to scene, and perhaps in between cuts?Towards the end, I'll analyze myself on a couch, seeking answers to some very existential questions, asking what makes life worthwhile, not for a moment giving credence to the thought that audiences might for a second find this self-despair unbelievable. Then I'll pull out the mouth organ my 17 year old high school lover gave me because she thought I might like to play it (right before I broke up with her). I'll run across the city, showing off all of its vibrancy in shades of gray. Gershwin will pipe in and out. The audience will know that my love interest is now legal even though I'm not making love to her at this point. "Where are her parents and family (does anyone care?)" they'll ask, while I'm stammering and murmuring my final lines of dialogue. I'll then think "why didn't I use Meryl Streep more?" and "why did I shoot in black and white and an aspect ratio that makes no sense?" and "thank God for Annie Hall" and "will a relationship with an underaged girl come back to haunt me?"I'll later want to burn the negatives on this film, offering to make two films in its place.4/10 stars

"Everyone gets corrupted. You have to have a little faith in people."First of all, I loved the decision to shoot this in black & white. It makes the city look completely beautiful, and it gives the whole thing a timeless feel. It suits the movie perfectly.Manhattan is basically about people that don't want what they have. Until they don't have it, of course. Then they want it desperately. Woody Allen's character Isaac is the worst offender. He tosses away jobs and girlfriends on a whim or an inkling of something more appealing on the horizon. Most of other main characters aren't much better. The story is encompassed within that circle of friends and relationships. I didn't find Manhattan to be as relatable and appealing as some of Allen's other movies that I've seen. The humorous dialogue didn't seem to be as sharp as I've come to expect, and there was really only one remotely likable character out of the lot. The ending is strong, thankfully, and that lessened the mild sense of disappointment that I felt about the film.Okay, but I don't consider it to be one of Woody's best.

reviews.review_title: MOVIE WITH LOVE... TO A CITY
reviews.content:
Woody Allen's Manhattan features black and white cinematography - by Gordon Willis - with a beauty rarely seen in the cinema.The movie is light, grand and balanced. Seen at first as a romantic comedy depicting the relationship between a middle-aged man and a teenager, the plot takes on complexities that only passionate people will be able to recognize. Isaac's and Tracy's romance does not thrive because of sheer immaturity ... of him.Although the romantic mood is always present, what you see most during the development of the plot are people who can't stand experiencing happiness and are always looking for justification to break up with their partners: Isaac persuades Tracy to leave it; Mary, who is having an affair with Yale, also asks him to leave her because he has no nerve to leave his wife; Yale himself encourages a relationship between Mary and Isaac to later regret.It seems that romances are a pretext for the director to celebrate his private love for Manhattan, a place he loves. From the opening of the movie, with dawn in Central Park to George Gershwin's Blue Rhapsody, to the iconic scene of the couple Mary-Isaac on a bench on Sutton Square overlooking the Queensboro Bridge, what follows is a sequence of New York rituals of that time: going to the Guggenheim Museum, art films, lake boats, concerts, Chinese food and a string of romantic songs performed mainly by the New York Philharmonic, under the baton of historic conductor Zubin Mehta.At the end of the movie, after meetings and mismatches, it seems that, along with Isaac, we all fell in love with Tracy aka Mariel Hemingway. Her acting is so natural and devoid of glamor that she seems to be the only person balanced within a multitude of beings utterly unable to get along serenely. When everyone introduces themselves, they speak not what they are but what they do, it is Tracy's most entertaining speech. After people say they are from TV, from the publisher, from literary criticism, she says:
I'm from high school.

*spoiler*  More serious than earlier Woodman but still great stuff.  Teen Mariel is nuts about Woody, he takes that for granted and moves on.  By the time he wises up she's gone.  Maybe the relationship is doomed from the start, but this movie captures Allen's eventual heartache as good as any (made more poignant in that he has only himself to blame).  Appropriately rewarded by Imdb voters.

In his final speech on "things that make life worth living", Isaac Davis mentions Groucho Marx, the second movement of Mozart's "Jupiter" Symphony, Louis Armstrong's recording of "Potato Head Blues", Flaubert's "A Sentimental Education" and so on to Tracy's face.  He makes one unforgivable omission which is a film called "MANHATTAN" by Woody Allen.  A genuine masterpiece to be seen and cherished over and over again.

reviews.review_title: Love, existentialism and Groucho Marx in New York
reviews.content: "Chapter One. He adored New York City. He idolized it all out of proportion". So begins Manhattan, the most shamelessly self-reflexive (if less autobiographical) opus produced by Woody Allen after a slew of much overdue critical hits. To many, it seemed Allen's idea bank had already run dry, re-treading territory he had explored to Oscar winning effect in 1977's Annie Hall and demonstrating little evidence of anything truly new. To those same skeptics, it became clear that although Allen tended to re-tread the same terrain, he also demonstrated an uncanny knack for continually extracting new nuggets of both profound and hilarious observations from that same source material, managing to make yet another film of people struggling to live and love in New York seem as fresh and vivid as ever. Indeed, in a contemporary context, Manhattan proves one of Allen's finest films, showcasing all of his defining elements at their most sharp, enormously charming and of course hysterically funny.One of the greatest misconceptions of Manhattan is that it serves as a mere Annie Hall-lite, its similar crafting of the ups and downs of a chaotic big city relationship (complete with Allen and Diane Keaton as the conflicted lovers to boot) making it only succeed as a secondary companion piece to the former. While debates over the quality of both films are ultimately a matter of individual opinion, it remains indisputable that Manhattan is a film of such vast scope and quality (and ultimately different intent) that to dismiss it as dwarfed by Annie Hall would be truly unforgivable. True to form, Manhattan does indeed proves yet another exploration of Allen's standard players in his beloved New York, but what makes the picture really stand out is how daringly ambiguous his character study is, crackling with as many shrewd meditations on romance, interpersonal dynamics and existential quests for meaning as his acerbic, gaspingly funny one-liners. This is a film piled full of refreshingly fallible people, complete with as many credible flaws as endearing personality quirks, making it more difficult to entirely devote one's sympathies to a singular character, but at the same time vastly increasing the realism factor and making the believability and vivid honest of the characters make them all the more appealing, flaws and all.However, despite the astute characterization being a highlight, it becomes abundantly clear that Allen's barely concealed intent was to craft a celluloid love letter to his favourite city, and as consequence, Manhattan is easily Allen's most visually gorgeous film, the crisp black and white cinematography drinking in every lusciously cinematic inch of the titular city with more tenderness than he captures any of his human characters. In many ways, Allen's Manhattan serves as somewhat of the antithesis of a film noir, revelling in his romanticized fantasy New York rather than exposing it seedy underbelly. The care and devotion Allen invests in his mise-en-scene is truly heart-warming, making the inherent sentimentality under the overcoat of neurotic cynicism inject real heart into the picture, making it all the more irresistible. As an actor as well as writer/director, Woody Allen continues his peak of stardom, by this point having his neurotic yet sporadically confident, wisecracking, sensitive and consistently self-serving persona so down pat he could easily (and likely did) do it in his sleep. Similarly, Diane Keaton essays a ditzy, impulsive and outspoken yet intelligent and vulnerable figure not at all unlike Annie Hall, but infused with such confidence and brimming charm and personality that despite her potentially repulsive intellectual pretension and shallowness, the viewer can't help but fall in love with her all anew all over again. Mariel Hemingway quietly and naturalistically oozes quirky wit and subdued pathos as Allen's consistently marginalized teenaged girlfriend, the emotional heart of the film, and Michael Murphy gives such a down to earth, credible performance that the viewer is never sold on whether to despise his serpentine charm or be drawn in by his earthy charisma. The legendary Meryl Streep also shines in a hilarious early role as Allen's now lesbian ex-wife, stealing scenes like the professional she was fated to become without ever derailing the focus of the picture. With Manhattan, Woody Allen reinforces his reputation as one of the most observative, insightful and hilarious filmmakers of his era, tackling familiar grounds with such a sharp tongue and teary eye that the viewer cannot help but be seduced. Any in search of comedy at its most jubilant, caustic and crucially genuine need look no further Manhattan - they are exceedingly unlikely to be disappointed.-9/10

Annie Hall was a classic that came out in 1978. I nearly loved it excluding the fact that it was slow. A year later, Manhattan was released. I loved it a lot more to some surprise. It actually turned out to be one of my top favorite Woody Allen films.My favorite Woody Allen film is Match point. In second place must be Manhattan. Cause it's so funny, so interesting, and very entertaining and in the end I haven't witnessed something so romantic in a Woody Allen film.The acting is all very good. Especially from Woody Allen and Mariel Hemingway. Allen here isn't a good guy, but a likable character. Hemingway, nominated for an Oscar in this movie, is adorable. I wonder what else she was in. She looks horribly familiar. Manhattan is a black and white film about a guy named Isaac(played by Woody Allen). Isaac is dating a seventeen year old(played by Mariel Hemingway)who he doesn't love. He has an ex-wife(played by a younger Meryl Streep)is a lesbian and is writing a book about their marriage. And Isaac has a crush on his best friend's girlfriend(played by Diane Keaton). Who at first he doesn't like and then grows onto her.Allen's character is a bad person. But he plays his usual goofy self so he's likable. You don't get that much from Diane Keaton as you did in Annie Hall. But the film's plot and everything is better than Annie Hall, which I still thought was an excellent film. Allen is a genius director and actor. Like all of his movies, Manhattan is worth seeing.Manhattan: A

I like this film very much, even today, allowing for the eerily prescient plot elements that mirror all that I like least about Woody now. Gershwin's music is used to perfection, with much evident love. Gordon Willis is a gifted, giftedcinematographer whose eye for line and composition reveals itself in black and white like it never could in color. Woody, as we all know, is the consummate film student as well as filmmaker, and here he absorbs and reflects the finest of1930s and 1940s New York location movies. Screwball comedy meets IngmarBergman in slap-happy film noir psychoanalytical angst. The script never falters. Wonderful work!

reviews.review_title: Why is life worth living? Groucho Marx, Swedish films, Tracy's face.
reviews.content: Having read the reviews of Woody Allen's Manhattan that precede mine, I feel quite inadequate and unable to completely and originally express my total and utter appreciation and admiration of this great film. Most have already seen and understand the beauty of Gordon Willis' black-and-white photography of New York City, the inspired wit and sophistication of Allen and Marshall Brickman's script, and the fine line Allen walks in directing between tragedy and comedy. Yet, how can I share in words how great an experience this film is? A psychiatrist could have a field day trying to dissect and analyze all the subconscious and hidden feelings and motivations that occur between the three main adult characters, but what it really breaks down to is that Isaac, Yale and Mary represent a part of nearly every human being that has or will attempt to start and maintain some sort of healthy and meaningful relationship. None of them seem to have the ability to share their feelings without any hindrance or caution at all; they all hide behind their own insecurities and excuses. In most romantic comedies today, these insecurities would be the central aspect of the characters; we would notice their acting out rather than their true agenda. Here, Allen is comfortable enough with the material to let the actors shine through and deeply express what each person really wants, or thinks they want.That being said, the acting here might be the best of any Woody Allen movie. Allen is great by toning down his usual stand-up persona and allowing the character of Isaac to really seep in and show himself as more than just neurotic and slightly narcissistic. Michael Murphy as Yale is also very good, somehow able to command our sympathy for someone who just might be the most unlikable person in all of Manhattan. But, Diane Keaton as the intellect Mary with enough personal issues to make Freud buy a new couch really steals the show and is in my mind, Keaton's best performance in a long and wonderful career. Her monologues when she discusses art and culture indicate someone who has learned all that is unnecessary to really live life. Indeed, Isaac even alludes to this, saying she truly knows nothing of what it means to feel like a person.There is also something extraordinary in the music Allen uses, particularly Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue. The film bookends with magnificent wide-angle shots of the overview of Manhattan and the music adds to the cinematography to create a feeling of wonder and awe; how can a city this terrific and life-changing be available to all of us to visit? This is really a love letter to NYC and having not been there before, I cannot express now how much I want to go if only to visit the museums and theaters and parks these people have available at their will.I cannot end this review without pointing to Mariel Hemingway's Oscar-nominated performance as Tracy, the 17-year old high-schooler who is the most honest and forthright of all the characters in her feelings and expressions. Perhaps Allen feels innocence and naiveté are the best form of allowing yourself to be honest. Her performance balances out the zaniness of the three leads and the final scene between her and Allen really strikes a note rarely seen in movies, much less romantic comedies. Roger Ebert said this is a film not about love in the present but love in the past; realizing you've lost a good thing and cannot recover. This is Allen's deepest regret and it is a testimony to help us understand that in every relationship we attempt, this outcome always lingers as a possibility.

The Three Acts:The initial tableaux: The film features some fine shooting in black and white. Isaac, 42, has drinks with his long time friend Yale, Yale's wife Emily, and Tracey, his current girlfriend, who is 17 (yikes). Isaac's ex Jill, who left him for another woman, is writing a tell-all book about their marriage. Isaac decides to quit his well-paying job to write a book.Delineation of conflicts: Isaac is not thrilled with Jill's book, but she is adamant about getting it published. Yale is having an affair with Mary, while Emily seeks the deeper commitment of children. Yale puts her off. Tracy would like Isaac to be happy, which is not ever going to be an easy thing. Isaac would like Tracy to have a normal happy youth; Tracy would like some commitment from Isaac. Isaac would like to be with his son more, but his obsession with intellect would probably never allow that. The triangle of Yale, Mary, and Isaac takes a number of turns, and has repercussions.Resolution: The personal connections move forward, some for better, some for the worse. Yep, that is about it, but it's well done.

I guess this is a great film if you like seeing 46 year old guys with 17 year old girls.  Honestly, did anyone see this movie and not see the trouble with Mia coming? If the age difference was supposed to be a joke Woody could have acted like it, he seemed on the verge of suicide throughout the movie.

What is the movie about? The title, MANHATTAN, tells the viewer what the movie is about. Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue" from its 1924 inception underscores a day in the big city, preferably--Manhattan. Note how often the camera is stationary as characters move into and out of camera range, but the camera doesn't move; clearly, characters--in search of what--are interlopers of the topic that is Manhattan. The Black & White cinematography creates a stripped down city without the clutter of color disrupting and disturbing; again reinforcing the notion that Manhattan is what the movie is about.I was never troubled by Woody Allen's interest in younger women; the theme is as old as humanity--David & Bathsheba comes to mind. When most 40+ year old women start sagging in all the wrong places and looking frumpy, older men get better looking. And don't kid yourself, the membrum virile still works with enthusiasm, even if not that of a 15 year old. So what older man doesn't pine for a younger woman. The downside-- a bodacious bod with an insipid mind. But that is another story. Though, if Mariel Hemingway continues to smoke, she too will soon enough start to look older than she is.Woody Allen was showing Manhattan with people interloping, spouting their nonsense about one thing or another, as in so many Woody Allan films. Another later New York Comic would create "a show about nothing" centered in Manhattan, a couple of years later; Woody Allan beat him to it.The Goofs section tells of "intellectual" Diane Keaton (as Marry Wilkie) mispronounces Diane Arbus as Diane and not as she herself pronounced her own name--Dee Anne. Well, who doesn't hear someone mispronounce a name (Van Gogh) and never say anything to correct the person; correcting being a sign of rudeness. Did Diane Keaton know how to pronounce Diane Arbus's name; did Woody Allan; do most people? It is the sort of detail that creates character and a moment in character, of character.Focus on "Manhattan" as the topic of the movie and let the characters be as interlopers, then let the characters fall into their proper place as irrelevancies against the backdrop of Manhattan.

reviews.review_title: In addition to being Allen's most visually striking film , Manhattan is also one of his most satisfying, considered by many his greatest achievement.
reviews.content: Manhattan is a masterpiece that has become a film for the ages by not seeking to be a film of the moment. The story is about Isaac Davis (Woody Allen), a twice-divorced 42-year-old comedy writer dating a 17-year-old high school girl (Mariel Hemingway). Isaac eventually falls in love with his best friend's mistress (Diane Keaton).The film is as close to a summation of Woody Allen's views and oeuvre as anybody needs; some smart jabs about the lives we lead are sometimes bogged down in earnestness and half-comic despair, while the protagonist's wildly unsuitable affair with a teenage girl is both funny and sorrowful. Allen takes Parks's lustrous black-and-white images of the city, combines them with Gershwin on the soundtrack and the result is irresistible. As funny as its immediate predecessor Annie Hall, but more sombre too. In 2001, the United States Library of Congress deemed Manhattan "culturally significant" and selected it for preservation in the National Film Registry.

reviews.review_title: This does not work for one main reason: Woody Allen.
reviews.content:
Manhattan is a movie that is hard to classify. It wants to be a romantic comedy, but there is not really any romance so to speak of. The movie is too cerebral to be romantic. There is not enough passion in the film and certainly not between the main protagonists. The whole plot is built around the love-triangle between Isaac, Mary and Yale, but there is never any tension or stakes. The romance in this movie is rather flat. There are some sweet moments indeed but it glaringly lacks passion. This is not a love story for the ages, it is merely the story of how Diane Keaton's character decides to give in and fool around a bit with Woody Allen. How Isaac went back to his previous girlfriend because he was out of options.
The movie works almost as a drama in that regard.Another issue is that there is humour in the movie but there are no real jokes. It is not a funny movie. You might find humour, ironic situations, but most of the comedy is character based.
Which brings me to the biggest culprit: Woody Allen himself. The Isaac characters is so close to his persona, which in turn mirrors his own life, that the whole movie's premise feels strange. When you are watching this movie, you are not really looking at the story of this writer caught up in a romantic intrigue; you are watching Woody Allen putting himself in these situations in order to look good. The whole subplot involving the underage girl is painful to watch, even if you are unaware of Allen's personal life.
The movie can be described as Allen putting himself in this series of uncomfortable and unsolvable situation. His character is frequently, if not always, the hapless victim in these situations. And worst of all, I can not really understand why. What is the reason to include the crazy pyscho ex-wife Meryl Streep? What was the point when Yale's wife telling him that she blames him for her husband's affair?
The movie wants us to feel pity for him, but he is not a lovable goof, he rather despicable. Just as Mary is by the way, but you don't hate Mary because the movie does not feel like a self-justification exercise.
In other words, the movie would have been better without Woody Allen in it.As a director, he is much more competent. It is a rather good-looking movie, there are great shots and every sequence, which is usually two characters talking to one another, is always dynamic and interesting. There is filmmaking craft here. The settings are all "exotic" yet it feels effortless and it gives the movie a very relaxed feeling and pace. It does give the feeling of a more intimate and simple story.
At the end of the day, you have a romantic comedy without jokes, where the romance is peripheral. It focuses on a character that is too similar to its real counterpart for comfort.

reviews.review_title: "I'm 42 and she's 17. I'm old enough to be her father."
reviews.content: Okay, it's a cheap shot but it's ironic how a film-maker that used art to imitate his life would end up imitating his art. The man who always writes himself as a neurotic Jewish-New Yorker with two ex-wives here spends the whole film coming to terms with his guilt over dating a younger girl.Manhattan seems to mark a maturation in style for Allen. I say "seems" as I must confess I'm no expert, having only watched eight of the thirty-one movies that see him as writer-star. Maybe the more adult narrative comes from Marshall Brickman as co-writer, but this one is more cohesive than the sketchy, fourth-wall breaking antics of "Annie Hall". A complete story from beginning to end, this one fills out it's 100 minute duration with no recourse for Allen to debate Fellini to the camera. This film also contains scenes (well, two) that don't feature Allen, though in fairness these scenes do mention Freud and generally revolve around Woody's character (here called "Issac Davis", not that character really matters with Woody).Davis is a comedy writer for tv and would-be novelist, whereas in Annie Hall he was a full-blown standup comedian. The marked difference between the two styles is that in the earlier film Woody's "character" is abrasive (or "displaying hostility as a counterpoint of sexual inadequacy", etc.) here it is softer, more reflective, less egocentric. Unfortunately this also makes him a lot less funny, and while the odd wry smile can be wrung out of this one I laughed out loud with Annie Hall.Allen's direction is also less frenetic, more suited to film here, though his imagery of New York as "black and white town that plays Gershwin" is (intentionally) second hand. Even the car journeys are breathlessly slow, whereas in "Hall" we see all numbers of crashes and breakneck rides. I can feel comparisons with "Annie Hall" flooding through on this one, and maybe it was a mistake for me to watch them back-to-back. Although I can see an advancement in Allen's writing-directing for this movie, I did prefer the previous film, as well as "Sleeper" and "Zelig" to this one. Finally, Manhattan closes briefly, for, no matter how good Woody's beginnings and middles are, he always seems to have trouble with an effective denouement.

reviews.review_title: A Vintage Woody Allen POSSIBLE SPOILERS
reviews.content: Anyone who has seen lots of Woody Allen movies knows that Allen has worked his way through many genres in his lengthy career. "Manhattan" belongs to the schlemiel-in-New York-with-woman-problems genre. The women in this case are Mariel Hemingway as Tracy, a 17-year-old high school girl with whom Woody as Isaac is having a torrid sex affair which she takes more seriously than he, Dianne Keaton as Mary, on the rebound from an affair with a married man who is Isaac's best friend, and Meryl Streep as Jill, Isaac's second wife who left him for a lesbian lover . Don't think of Streep as a leading actress; in this film, she's a gorgeous but secondary figure, and there are no romantic sparks whatsoever between Isaac and Jill. The dynamic is Isaac-Tracy, Isaac-Mary, then back to Isaac-Tracy (too late) when Mary recommits to her married lover and he elects to leave his wife. Isaac literally runs back to Tracy who has taken advice he gave her when they were breaking up to go to study in London. He's changed his mind because he's desperate but she's going any how. And though she expects to return in six months, it's clear that Isaac believes they will never be reunited.Along the way, Woody exposes his familiar neuroses and spills out his jokes here, there and everywhere. "Manhattan" is one of the better in this particular genre of Woody Allen's works. Keaton executes her role as a flightly, opinionated, insecure Radcliffe girl with great skill, Hemingway is convincing, and Streep in her brief screen time displays the promise that has made her into one of the great screen actresses of our time. Woody is the Woody we all know in this genre, and that's pretty good.

reviews.review_title: Likeable and bright comedy about urban living
reviews.content: A TV gagman quits his job in the heat of the moment and takes up with a girl that he knows is far too young for him.One of these solid and workmanlike films - told in black and white - that seems like nothing in the telling, but it effects more than average because most of things that happen on screen ring true. Great dialogue from Allen and Brickman and a likable cast help paint the funny, tragic and confused world that our hero lives in.While delivering nothing new and not reaching the heights of Annie Hall (no Oscars this time), it is a bang-on-the-money look at urban life today and its various ups and downs. It all looks so simple and anyone-can-do it, but very few directors actually can. Falls short of being  a classic, but as a piece of entertainment it is far too good to miss.

I've read some of the comments here and I was enrage by some of them.Especially "Woody Allen haters"( read the awful reviews of  "sddavis63" from Canada or "ajdagreat").Even a fellow named "brando70" considers Allen A rapist? that"he was repulsed" by the relationship between Isaac and Tracy.Give me a break!.Does America still have unbearable moralist like that?.A relationship between an older man and a young mature woman shouldn't be seen as "immoral".In this film Tracy and Isaac,their  relationship is the most healthy of the entire movie.How could that  be negative?.SO,IF YOU HATE WOODY ALLEN,stop wasting your time(and ours)  in writing bad things about him,instead go and read the bible or rent "Jaws" on DVD!.

reviews.review_title: A great film from Woody Allen
reviews.content: Woody Allen's film about a love triangle involving a divorced man(Allen) who is dating a 17 year old (Hemingway) but begins to fall for Mary(Keaton) who is Yale (Murphy)'s mistress. Meanwhile Allen's ex-wife (Streep) now has a female partner and is writing a book about her divorce and relationship with Isaac (Allen). The film is very quirky, typical Woody, and pretty funny at times. It didn't reach the peak of such films as Annie Hall, Purple rose of Cairo and Match Point, but its definitely a great film. I liked the performances, especially Woody himself, Keaton and Streep. Boy did Woody know how to direct some intellectual comedies, and pretty much he still has the touch these days.--- 9/10

I'm a big fan of Woody Allen. His humour is crisp and dry, his films are unpretentious and entertaining, and everything flows like an insightful vignette of life - like art this isn't conscious of being art. Nonetheless, I am a little disappointed with "Manhattan".Let's face it: it's just "Annie Hall" again with a reworked plot. Aside from the obvious similarities, like Allen playing the main role alongside Keaton, his character is identical. Save the change of name, they both have the same neuroses (which is, indeed, a hallmark of an Allen film), and are both trying to pick up the pieces after a second divorce. Allen's relationship with Keaton is the same in both films: in both they fall in and out of love, and in both she ultimately rejects him.Truthfully, the plot of "Manhattan" has more social depth to it: there is more than one relationship being examined, and a fall-out also occurs with a good friend. The ending of "Manhattan" is decidedly different to the ending of "Annie Hall" as well, but "Annie Hall" supports itself with greater strength. Besides, "Annie Hall" was a cinematographic experiment of enormous scope; "Manhattan"'s claim to artistic fame was the fact that it was not shot in colour. There appears to be little development in Allen's craft in the two short years between releasing one and the other.I think that "Manhattan/Annie Hall 2" is a good film, and worth seeing if you happen to be a fan. Otherwise, just stick with the original.

reviews.review_title: Woody's Best Shots Of New York. Mariel Hemingway Is Awesome.
reviews.content:
I love the black and white - this particular film is better in black and white.
I love the stationary camera with prolonged shots of the city.
Mariel Hemingway shines.
Woody's character is despicable, but somewhat charming.
One of my favorite Woody Allen films. With a re-write of the last scene, it could have been his best film. He was still learning...RealReview Posting Scoring Criteria:

reviews.review_title: A movie that does not age well
reviews.content:
An ode to Hollywood's obsession with sexualizing minors. If this movie was made today it would be called, "Grooming."
It's hilarious how pathetic Allen's character is.Was he actually looked up to for this "back in the day?"

reviews.review_title: A simple story about less than simple characters.
reviews.content: New York, New York the backdrop of wistful big-band jazz ballads, countless movies, photography, landmarks and historical figures born, raised and blossoming on its sidewalks, avenues and skyscrapers. Yet for all of its pomp and circumstance—for all it's King Kongs, Marshmallow Men, John McClanes and Jerry Seinfelds, the realm of the screen whether it's on or off the big one, is one that is notably short on the romantic side of the story. Rarely is it evident that the city itself plays its own character, reflected by the characters, their bond and their adventure into the often daunting, unpredictable and—most of all—unknowing world of love,romance and ensuing comedy.It has largely been up to astute writer and director Woody Allen then to convey New York's softer but all the more vicious side. Through Allen we are treated to glimpses of love through the somewhat romanticized lens of New York City; imperfect, busy, chaotic and downright obnoxious at times, but nevertheless just as charming, larger than life and down-to-earth as you might imagine. Through this common aesthetic in most of Mr. Allen's features therein lies a thin thread of continuity and of consistency that makes his movies his own. Sitting down to watch Manhattan then is something of a reminiscent but nevertheless compelling and surprising experience regardless of whether you have seen the feature or not. Yet for all intents and purposes, Manhattan comes at the end of what is perhaps the director's finest era in cinema and so while it may come across as overly familiar, there are still plenty of little flairs and elaborations of theme that Woody portrays here (and arguably perfects) that in a way redefine both his craft, his ever-persistent love for New York, and his ability to convey that love and bizarre consciousness on screen.Centring around an ensemble of five characters, the story of Manhattan is one that Woody has told countless times over the years, and to mixed effect yet this is never truly the point to his films. Instead, this somewhat convoluted mish-mash of relationship turmoil, confusion and neurosis serves as a catalyst for characterisation of those central characters. Through their complicated love triangles, conflicts of heart and head amongst other things—Manhattan tells a simple story about less than simple characters, their relationships and the city that serves as their roof whilst they have it out with each other.I mean, to simply state that the premise of the entire feature revolves around a 42-year-old male character who is torn between his best friend's mistress of sorts and a 17-year-old intelligent young female who has fallen for his maturity—to say that this serves as the raw building blocks for the tale that Allen spins here will be of no shock to anyone at all knowledgeable on the director, but will nevertheless convey just what is involved here to those unenlightened with his traits. There are film-makers who strive for epic grandiose and shocking derailments of the human psyche and yet here Allen does it without even trying; he's the master of the simple complication; of the everyday niggles that haunt us and distract us from our greater aspirations and Manhattan is probably the perfect culmination of all those elements from previous works.As alluring and captivating as of all this higgilty-piggilty back-and-forth squash interplay between characters against the startlingly beautiful and romantic black and white compositions of New York city spliced over larger than life musical numbers can be however—Manhattan is just as much a bittersweet comedy as it is romance and philosophical tragedy of sorts. Playing his central character as he has so far been accustomed to by the time with part neurosis and part self-assured conviction, Allen not only serves as the film's most identifiably human character, but also serves as a fine source of disconnected entertainment and amusement also. From the razor sharp wit prevalent in most of the characters' dialogue to the rapport that they each share whether it's discussing love, sex, art, life or philosophy; Allen's script is one steeped in intelligence, charm and grace—too often film-makers will shove such elements down throats in an attempt to convey their intellect, and yet once again Woody does it subtly and with a refrain that allows the feature to remain light, highly comical and most of all, romantic.As the years have gone on since Manhattan first graced screens just over three decades ago, the romantic comedy as it is known has become something of a belittled, and confused shadow of its former self. Yet it is a testament not only to the best of films' ability to withstand the test of time but also of the film-maker himself that Manhattan still to this day feels revitalising, prompt and absolutely relevant. Maybe it's the timeless photography by Gordon Willis that renders New York in shades of a wistful dream; or maybe it's the fact that Manhattan is first and foremost a movie about us, who we are and what makes our hearts skip beats when we least expect them to. Whatever it may be, it goes without saying that what Allen achieves here is nevertheless something of a definable milestone for the genre and of cinema itself. It's got heaps of romance that stays true to what it really feels like to be in such perplexing situations, plus a firm sense of personality, razor sharp wit and endlessly engrossing performances that seal the deal right from the get-go; but most of all it's the perfect embodiment of Allen's interest in the simplest of confusing human complications—love. Whether it's for a girl or a city, you just can't ever seem to pin it down, phrase it or convey it just the way you want to."No, no, start again. Chapter One" Written by Jamie Robert Ward(http://www.invocus.net)

reviews.review_title: Neurosis Worship Peppered with Ace Craftsmanship
reviews.content: The more I experience Woody Allen, the more I feel he is to cinema what seafood is to cuisine: a acquired taste for sure, distasteful to many, worshiped by many more... Since with Annie Hall this film represents the pinnacle of Allen's cinema, your enjoyment of it will depend on your ability to empathize and sympathize with his intense brand of neurosis and self-absorption. I'll attribute my rating to not yet really knowing where I stand in that regard.On the plus side, this is the most refreshing love-story since Harold and Maud - the latter being arguably a better and more sincere film - and while not always likable, Allen's Isaac is a fascinating, endlessly watchable and quotable creature. On a more technical level, there is also, for lovers of film, some sheer delight to be had at just watching Woody handling scenes and sustaining dramatic or comedic tension. The craftsmanship behind the film is undeniable: Allen's trademark mastery of the unbroken shot, together with legendary cinematographer Gordon Willis' unparalleled lighting and sense of composition, make this one of the most beautiful films about New York.If you want to explore vintage Woody, it's probably easier to start with the more playful Annie Hall, but this is then as accomplished as he gets while still placing himself firmly at the center of his work. The more easily irritated viewer might want to ease him or herself into his films by watching the less self-absorbed Match Point or Vicky Christina Barcelona first.

Anyone who has read my other reviews is aware that I am most definitely not a fan of writer/director/actor Woody Allen. I absolutely abhor Broadway Danny Rose, Bullets Over Broadway and Hannah and Her Sisters, films that Allen afficionados place at the peak of his canon of work. That is not to imply, however, that I hold all of his films in such contempt.For instance, I think Manhattan ranks as one of the best films of the 1970s and certainly one of Allen's very best. Ironically, it remains a film that even Allen's fans often forget until reminded of it. More drama than comedy, although it has some amusing moments, the film functions as a lovingly crafted valentine to the joys of New York City, while simultaneously focusing on the messed up love lives of its primary characters.Allen predictably casts himself in the central role of a dissatisfied divorced New Yorker, still reeling from his break-up with former wife Meryl Streep (in a throwaway role). He has stumbled into a relationship with jailbait high school student Mariel Hemingway, but despite her seriousness he refuses to consider it as anything more than a passing infatuation. He instead falls in love with the sophisticated mistress of his best friend (played by Allen regular Diane Keaton), which carries its own set of problems.The storyline is a lot more focused than many of Allen's efforts. His strange desire to film this in black and white would seem the height of pretension, but it actually comes off quite well. I have never been a fan of Allen the actor and often think that some of his films would have worked better had he recused himself from leading man duties - this one is no exception. That said, to deny that Allen does not have his effective moments would be erroneous. For a change, he actually fits into the action rather than seeming inserted into it.Of the supporting cast, Streep is barely in the film long enough to make much impact. Michael Murphy, as Allen's best friend, struggles with an ill-conceived role. The performances to watch are the two main actresses. I am usually not a big fan of Keaton's work, which I think is often mannered and off-putting. Here, she shucks many of her trademark mannerisms and creates a complex lead character. It is one of her best performances. Hemingway - in her best performance - scores in a role that could easily have been embarrassing. Allen has a predilection for casting himself as the romantic interest opposite actresses that are ridiculously too young for him - and given the later scandal that erupted around him - it becomes obvious that it mirrors his own tastes. This film is no exception, with Allen robbing the cradle with a worshipful high school student. The reason why this subplot works is because Hemingway sells it so well. We honestly see no reason for her to be especially entranced by Allen, but when she confides that it is because she finds him funny and charming, we believe that she believes it. The dramatic scene in the mid section of the film where Allen tries to sympathetically dump her to pursue Keaton while cushioning the blow is well done, but it is especially telling of Hemingway's mature performance that we do not honestly wonder for a moment whether she might not end up being the more logical and well-suited love interest - especially with some years to mature.The film is a veritable buffet of beautiful cinematography. It is an incredibly romantic film, but the irony comes from the fact that the romance emerges less from the characters, but from New York City itself. Allen obviously loves New York, but this is one of the few times that he has successfully fine-tuned that "romance" and presented it on screen in a way that can be unilaterally shared with his viewers.
