Manhattan is the standard by which all of Woody Allen's -- and everyone else's -- movies about relationships should be judged.  It's funny, touching, sad, and profound, and I find something new in it every time I watch it (which is well past 20 times at this point).  Relationships and life are messy and complex, and Woody's narrative shows this so effortlessly, I think, that people overlook how complex and elegant this movie is.  It's also shot beautifully in B&W, and the all-Gershwin soundtrack is sublime.  As always, Woody's story and character are semi-autobiographical, and in retrospect, his real-life affair with/marriage to Soon-Yi makes his relationship in the story to a 17-year old Mariel Hemingway a little needlessly weighty.  But still, it ranks as my all-time favorite movie to watch alone.

This was the first Woody Allen movie that I have seen and all I can say is that it was a whirlwind experience. The dialogue is quick and funny at times and the fact that Allen decided to film in black and white was an interesting decision but seemed to capture the beauty of "Manhattan".I think there are many different interpretations people can have about what this movie is about but to me, it seemed to come down to a character played by Allen, "Ike", who wasn't sure what he wanted. He lives a complex life and seems to make relationships of both friends and lovers much more complicated than it has to be by his own conduct and views on things. The character development of Ike with his relationship with his young girlfriend and then having an affair with his friend Yale's wife was anxiety producing and funny. Allen captured a lot of what Manhattan is known for, culture, art and sophistication. I enjoy the actual borough of Manhattan and love visiting but I am not sure that I would want to actually know and be friends with a character like Ike.

A great movie with a combination of comedy and romance. The movie as a whole was really good but there was some things that I found a little strange. I didn't understand why the couple was not so compatible with each other. The relationship was not what you imagine a couple in movie to be like. One of the scenes that I thought was interesting and the acting was really good because you can feel what the character/characters are portraying. The acting in this movie was great and it was one of the factors that made you want to continue watching the movie after each scene passed.

Manhattan-**** (out of 4): Woody Allen broke his strictly comic image with 1977's "Annie Hall" and he followed that effort up with this masterpiece, a work of such beautiful cinematography, pitch-perfect writing, and an unforgettable cast. The opening black and white scenes of Manhattan, set to the pitch of "Rhapsody in Blue" by George Gershwin makes NYC come alive like it never has before. Then, we get to the story, with a group of neurotic New Yorkers struggling to keep their emotional lives in tact. Mariel Hemingway is absolutely fantastic above all the others, she breathes pure sensitivity into her part as Woody's teen-aged lover. "Manhattan" was Allen's first effort to capture the spirit of NYC as a whole and its intellectual community. However, this film functions as more than a love note to New York, it also is a highly personal movie about romance, friendship, and intellectual angst.

reviews.review_title: A beautifully filmed, witty pedophile fantasy
reviews.content: I just re-watched this movie recently. I loved it in college, and thought Woody was a genius. The dialogue and story are still great, the cinematography is beautiful, and New York City shines as a majestic, romantic city. Woody's depiction of the neurotic intellectual elite crowd in Manhattan is entertaining and hilarious.But today I see something sinister here that I didn't twenty years ago. Maybe it has to do with the whole twisted Soon Yi-Mia business that happened in the subsequent years. Maybe it's because now that I'm the age of Ike Davis, I realize how screwed up it is for a guy in his forties to be dating a high school student. Maybe now that I have daughters of my own, I know I'd never want them to get involved with a 42 year-old guy when they were still wearing braces.Strip away the learned banter about Kafka and Bergman, the great black and white shots of the city, the wry, pithy remarks from Ike, and this movie essentially glorifies and presents as healthy what is legally considered statutory rape. If you want to be really blunt about it, you might say that this movie is a pedophile's fantasy. Ike Davis's manipulation and mistreatment of Tracy is ultimately treated as not such a bad thing. Tracy, the pure, sweet, yet sexually wild nymphet (talk about the pedophile's fantasy!) accepts it all, and remains loyal to her 42 year-old man. Ike's constant complaints to his friends about how he realizes Tracy is too young and how he has to get out of the relationship are supposed to show that he's not some predatory sicko but a normal guy who shares the audience's moral perspective.Yet he ultimately discards any concerns he has about the propriety of his relationship with Tracy. He concludes that his relationship with Tracy is the best one he's ever had with a "woman" and wants her to cancel her 6-month trip to London so she can get back together with him. She tells Ike that had he come to her a week earlier, she might have considered it. But not to worry, says Tracy: "What's six months if we both love each other?". Despite Ike having cheated on her, dumped her, and repeatedly told her that he's unwilling to commit to her, Tracy still regards him as her true love. So again, it's the pedophile's fantasy: this isn't an abusive, inappropriate relationship--it's true love! Ike's mistreatment of Tracy and taking advantage of her childlike naïveté is not morally wrong--see, she still loves him and wants more! The best partner for a 42 year-old accomplished intellectual man is not an accomplished intellectual woman the same age like Diane Keaton's character--no, it's a girl in high school! I read an article in the NY Times recently about how, given the increased awareness of sexual abuse of children that has emerged since 1979, a movie like Manhattan could never get made today. That's probably not such a bad thing. Back in the 80s, I read a glowing review of Manhattan that talked about Ike Davis's smile in the final scene when Tracy tells him he has to have a little more faith in people. That smile was so profound, said the reviewer, the perfect expression of the complex emotions in the lives of these elite intellectual New Yorkers. I agreed with the reviewer 20 years ago. But when I re-watched the movie the other day, all I could think was that if it was my daughter this guy was preying on, if I saw that smile I'd want to punch him in the face.

reviews.review_title: Great cinematography does not a great movie make.
reviews.content: I enjoyed Manhattan, I really did. I've lived in New York for almost my entire life and the shots of Manhattan were brilliant and beautiful. But that alone does not make for a great film. It's certainly worthy of a viewing, but I think it's over rated by most people. Is it good? Yes. Great? Hardly. I give it a 6 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: A visual love letter to New York .. you will fall in love with Manhattan!
reviews.content: Woody Allen's 'Manhattan' sores a perfect 10 rating from me because it is faultless. I have never seen a more beautiful visual love letter to New York as this one, in which Woody Allen manages to encapsulate all he adores about NY to a gorgeous score and a razor sharp screenplay.With a dynamic ensemble cast including Diane Keaton as a neurotic intellectual, marvellous Meryl Streep (looking lovely!) as Allen's lesbian ex-wife, and Mariel Hemmingway as the teenage object of Allen's affections, the witty screenplay is brought to life with humour and also a little pathos.The city of New York is, as any visitor or inhabitant will know from experience, magical, and Allen captures this essence in 'Manhattan'. The film looks stunning in black and white, and the accompanying Gershwin score feels as if it were written specially to be used by Allen.At the end of the film, Woody Allen's character lists all that he feels is wonderful about life. If I had to make the same list, this film would feature. It is a true classic and is not to be missed. I rate 'Manhattan' and 'Annie Hall' as Woody Allen's finest accomplishments.

I just said I loved this movie, yes of course I do and especially for the ending. Terrific, as they use to say trough though all over the movie. I am personally watching all Woodie Allen movies. I watched "Bananas", "Everything you always wanted to know about sex" and this is the third one I'm watching. Well, I would say that his style has grown a lot. So stylish now, If in the first comedy we can see the genius and silly curiosity of the young director. Now his style is clear: Love at first place, and always focusing on the relationship between man and woman, not from man side, not from woman side. Just on the Relationship between them. So innocent and at the same time effective. I love the way he is able to makes the audience see all the 360° spectrum of couple's issues. Great, absolutely great. And at my 25 years old age I can say I saw myself in ALL of them! How forward Woodie is.If I gotta say a critic to balance I still think he could be a little bit more into the situations, too much into his ironic character I think, but this is a personal opinion, and I'm just say this because I think he is great and soo hard to find something not good in his Terrific works.So 9/10. Great prove of Meryl Streep, I really appreciate the innocent passion of the Heminghway, terrific in the last scene, and good choice of B/W. The only color mentioned was "The brown water".Absolutely to watch, I'm so sorry I just saw it at 25 years old!!! And by the way...I'm watching it over again!See ya, Roberto

reviews.review_title: Woody Allen's stunning ode to New York.
reviews.content: Has New York ever looked this good? The film tells the story of Isaac (Woody Allen), a semi successful TV writer who falls in love with his best friends neurotic mistress (Diane Keaton). Now I'm not really a sucker for romantic comedies but when they're done this good you just have to hold your hands up and applaud. Woody Allen blends romance with comedy effortlessly with a script that's loaded with humour, intelligence and wit. The film boats excellent performances from all of it's cast, most notably Woody Allen and Diane Keaton. The main character in the film however is Manhattan itself, the cinematography of the film really is something to behold, possibly the best looking film I've ever seen. The visuals coupled with the excellent soundtrack add an extra layer of the depth and beauty to the film, perfectly capturing the feel of the city. Underneath it all, it's a film about life, love and loss. Highly recommended.10/10

Manhattan: A DVD Movie ReviewThis is my second favorite Woody Allen film, funny, but the one I cry over, the one that elicits anguish, the one that makes me think about morality, and what is right and wrong. The George Gershwin music track and black and white cinematography of the great city of New York are compelling cinema, in this unique work of late 20th century art. An amazing movie but, despite being alarming funny, it is so very sad. Is it Woody's aim as a filmmaker to make the audience laugh and cry at the same time? Perhaps. Woody is very clever, but he is no genius, and because he thinks he is, this is downfall. Regardless, "Manhattan" is a truly great film.Once again Diane Keaton is Woody's straight woman amongst shtick, and in this cinema she is heartbreakingly beautiful. Her cheekbones rise and fall to new heights and lows, and her lyrical voice and disarming gestures are frankly hard not to fall in love with. But Diane is not alone as cast in this fascinating film, as there are many other supportive actors and actresses in this story, all very good, and all necessary to tell the story.The story is about a TV script writer, played by Woody, that tires of the mundane and phony grind of the everyday. He is admired by New York's culture for being intellectual and witty, but he can't take the phoniness of it anymore and quits his job to pen the great American novel. Of course, without money, or a job, a man is a bum, and this eats away at the Allen character.Within the thread of this brilliant film is a tall tiny fragile flower. A 17 year old girl that has a serious infatuation with the 42 year old Woody character. Telling is a moment of dialog in this film, when Diane Keaton's character asks this young girlfriend, Tracy was her name, what she does, and she innocently and primly says "I go to High School". This sets a sort of tone to the emotional end to this film. This young girl was portrayed with a sad and final very hard bitten lesson, by a young actress with an ethereal beauty in one Mariel Hemingway. And finally I can't omit, an ex-wife of Woody's character, playing a lesbian, an act that is so very out of character, in a very early role, of one stunning blond in Meryl Streep.The final chapter in this very good story is about that young afore mentioned High School girl. When Mariel, as Tracy, implores, and looks at the imploring heel played by Woody, and says, "You really hurt me", this little line says it all. Young people should not mix around with the old, because it is the old that controls the emotion of love. I know that all too well having had to deal with age differences in relationships. But still . . .To really experience this movie, and the failure of human relationships contained within, is to imagine you are Tracy, the young girl acted, aptly, and so very sadly by Mariel Hemingway. She breaks my heart every time in black and white weeping. It is how I view this film and when I feel her hurt, I really take in this experience, and I feel young, but betrayed by love and age.This film is a 1970's period piece. Manhattan's sky line is old. The cars are relics. The human relationships are a cliché of that era. That is, except, for the love that the young Tracy feels for Woody Allen's character Isaac. And through all the weaving in and out of lies, cheating, and what could be, it is the young woman's love, for an older man, that is brought forth as true. Woody realizes this almost too late, but you have that feeling, that that spring and fall relationship will not work. Because in the end, it is the young girl who grows up, illustrating the immaturity of Woody's character. Classic stuff.A really great film, despite the director's excuses, I give it 9 out of 10 stars.B. A. Draper

reviews.review_title: Most entertaining if you've lived in the New York area.
reviews.content: I liked this ode to New York City much better than the more acclaimed Annie Hall. Although Mariel Hemingway does get to be a bit of a drag. Watching this boredom that she fomments is necessary to appreciate the Allen character's feelings. She just got to be too much of a problem. I know one should be sympathetic towards her, but she is such a whiner, such a cute young one. One ends up wondering why he does not like the Keaton character infinitely better. Let's remark about the famous credits, since the film boasts one of the most famous credits in movie history. I have a copy of this one and have seen it dozens of times.

reviews.review_title: A letter written by Woody to his hometown
reviews.content: Director Woody Allen presents his movie Manhattan (1979), which follows different characters through their various relationships.It's a simple story, told in a linear fashion, which speaks of honesty in relationships, because throughout the film we see the characters say "truths" and "lies" in order to achieve to be with the person they want and be happy.It becomes a letter written by Woody to his hometown, because it presents a lot of what he feels about New York, so that saves a lot of realism and everything becomes believable, and the protagonist is so well built that from the beginning of the movie , we hear his voice and drew him in our mind without even seeing it. It is a film that goes beyond just being a romantic comedy, has sad moments, happy, funny, romantic, etc. .. everything as it happens in real life, and leads the characters through all these emotions in a natural way, so that nothing feels forced.It shows a contrast between the protagonist and his goals in life, because in general we see him as a person "failed" who wants to get high, but he seriously believes he can achieve it, and there's much of the comedy and he creates empathy with the public, because it is a very human character.It's a comedy that could be called "serious" because, in general, what is laughable is how the characters face common situations that could happen to anyone. The script is written so that the story flows very fast, every time something happens, it has a lot of dialogue, but it works because it is not explanatory, but it gives the viewer the information he needs to know at that time, no all he wants to know.Allen shows us a project that embodies much of his thinking, his outlook on life and we see this primarily with the protagonist, who seeks love, to make sense of life and fill a void.

reviews.review_title: Woody should have won an Oscar
reviews.content: This film is a masterpiece and think Woody's best. Though 'Annie Hall' is my favorite. As a longtime devote to Sir Allen, I was very impressed with this film. From the opening narration and the shots of the city, you are hooked.Allen's use of black & white is a great touch, it really adds allot of charm and character(as if it needed it) to the city of Manhattan.The acting is great and the dialogue is witty and sharp. Woody's deals with dating a young girl and how he takes her for granted. And quitting his job as a tv sitcom writer. Allen takes advantage of the beautiful city around him and takes us into his world.'Manhattan' succeeds where many films fail. It gives us interesting dialogue and complex protagonist. Allen proves that you dont need computer graphics to make a great film.**** out of **** stars. One of the best films of the seventies.

reviews.review_title: Woody Allen at his absolute best.
reviews.content: Nobody denies what a superb director Woody Allen is his status is that of America's premier director in my opinion and if your familiar with his work then surely you must agree with me if I said that Manhattan is his greatest work? There is only one word that can be used to describe this film and that is a true masterpiece both intellectually and visually. In my opinion this film shows Woody Allen at the absolute peak of his career, its shot in Black and White but yet in Widescreen format and it really worked well it makes for breathtaking cinematography. I must say that even Woody Allen's command of the situation and the dialogue are just really top notch if possible even better than his usual legendary performances. There is a real bitter-sweet heartfelt angst between each of the characters. I think this film is a real tribute from Woody Allen to the city he loved so much.

reviews.review_title: It doesn't get much better than this!
reviews.content: This film will long live as one of Woody Allen's masterpieces. It's hard to think how it could be improved, even though Woody himself has commented that he felt that the final cut of the film (i.e. that we have seen) is too dark. There are always hours of footage that don't make it to the final version but I can't imagine how it could be better or more powerful.

Still the best film Woody Allen has made (and he's made plenty of wonderful ones), "Manhattan" is to my mind practically flawless, from the brilliant writing and acting to the stunning black-and-white photography and the delightful Gershwin-filled soundtrack.  It's certainly one of the ten best films of the 70's (a decade with plenty of great films), and one of my favorite movies of all time.

reviews.review_title: Great, but Why? (Contains very vague but possible spoilers)
reviews.content: I'm not sure if Manhattan is Woody Allen's greatest film, but I have agreed with the overwhelming vote of other reviewers that it's great--until I saw it again a few weeks ago, and I remembered why I also disliked it. I haven't read all of the reviews, but the recent ones seem to dodge the key issue--why would anyone like 'Manhattan'? The problems are obvious: the Allen and Keaton characters should make any normal viewer want to puke. Then the movie celebrates NYC by implying that these characters deserve our sympathetic attention and identification. The prime example, Allen's character, is frankly grotesque. He's an obviously total scumbag in connection with Hemingway, but in all other ways, too. He even hogs the basketball when he picks up his son to pass an afternoon away. When Keaton voices interesting ideas, he responds with dumb self-centered whining--God, his character is one trait = whine. Of course, to balance things, writer Allen makes Keaton's character almost equally puke-worthy--interpersonally dishonest, pathologically insecure but still smugly self-promoting.... A flaw in the film is that Hemingway's honesty and maturity can't be articulated in the space of the other characters; her final speech sounds too good to be true, so maybe she's just learned to lie the New Yorker way in rationalizing self-centered choices, as opposed to really maintaining a commitment to Allen.I don't think these are insights--I imagine that Allen the auteur would agree, all of the film characters actually do agree when they have occasion to reflect and edge toward honesty...they're the raw material of the film. But the characters go on to be fascinating, dynamic, somewhat sympathetic, maybe even prototypical of NYC. How does this black (yes, evil, I'd affirm--we should, but do not, blanch at Allen's treatment of Hemingway in the last scene) magic happen? Why do we consent to the puke and find the humor and life? Possible answers: They're anti-heroes--no, antiheroes have positive dispositions (see Annie Hall), missing here. They're clinically interesting--no, they're too appealing for that. They're comic--yeah, but the 'Manhattan' character arc is not the 3 Stooges. They're 'real'--no, frankly, Allen comes too close to giving us the 3 Stooges; the people, even the New Yorkers, I know are not bad like this.I'm married to a New Yorker, so maybe I'm just a sucker for the NYC vibe, but my wife, past the fast talk, is a lot like the Hemingway character in earnestness. I have no good answer, but I fear that people who totally love the film may be getting brainwashed past the basic contradiction.

reviews.review_title: Manhattan - A Stupendous Movie About Dating and Relationships.
reviews.content: I can't think of a more charming and thought provoking movie about dating and relationships than Manhattan. It possesses such realistic dialog and probing commentary on the desperate nature of human beings in search of love. Also it demonstrates Woody's unrequited love for Manhattan, which is firmly stated in the introductory narration. Although I haven't been to Manhattan, I have read numerous accounts stating that Woody Allen has captured the essence of Manhattan in this movie. This is what it feels like. Through Allen's lenses we are also seeing what a City is supposed to be.I was amused to see Woody Allen's character Isaac sticking up for the 'only genius' he knows in Cinema - Ingmar Bergman. Referring to a new acquaintance who is the lover of his best friend, Isaac says to his 17 year old girlfriend, '...if she had made one more remark about Bergman, I would've knocked her other contact lens out.' The dialog is so sharp that it's always one step ahead of the viewer. You really don't know where the next frenetic thought of Allen will take you. Just don't expect someone to shrug their shoulders, slap their forehead and with mid-rising intonation say d'uh! It's not that kind of comedy. It's not the show, 'Friends'. Manhattan contains perplexing and often dark adult humor. The other aspect of Manhattan which struck me was just how influential it must have been on the hugely successful 90's sit com Seinfeld and the subsequent Larry David self mockumentary, Curb your Enthusiasm. The characterizations and conversation themes are just too similar. Elaine Benes is almost a direct copy of Diane Keating's 'Mary'. Her mannerisms, modern feminism attitude and even her outfits have an uncanny resemblance to Allen's Mary. Jason Alexander did say in the Seinfeld Chronicles that when he auditioned he did basically a straight up imitation of Woody Allen. 'It was all Woody' or words to that effect.Woody Allen is a wonderful actor. It wasn't something I had fully appreciated until seeing this. The real eye opener for me however was his 17 year old lover played by Mariel Hemmingway. Her sensitivity and vulnerability shone so brightly - a truly incredible and touching performance, and from one so young.Oh and other things like the irrepressibly beautiful soundtrack and cinematography. Well that would require another review to mention the superlatives of each.I found Manhattan a completely different movie to Annie Hall, but in an improved sense. The story seemed to have more vigor and I admired the acting a heck of a lot more. I might have been expecting too much from Annie since it was my first Allen movie and it had been parodied to death. I need to see both movies again to be more conclusive about which I like better. One thing is for certain, 'Manhattan' is a fantastic dating movie. If you want something to provoke an insightful relationship conversation with your better half, then Manhattan is it! I'm looking forward to seeing Hannah and her Sisters next. Supposedly Allen didn't like Manhattan, which surprises me, but I wonder was it because its totality or essence was a bit close to home? I've noticed his more recent movies involve stories which far less encapsulate an 'introspective' Woody and more driven towards showcasing other uniquely neurotic characters and harder driven stories and plots.It's this Jewish humour (is this the Lenny Bruce genre everyone talks about?), which undoubtedly is my favourite style of humour because it is so witty and introspective and doesn't belittle the audience's intelligence.... on the contrary.The verdict? This is essential 'Allen', me thinks, despite what Woody may think.

Though not considered so by most, I believe this to be Woody Allen's best film. It fulfills all emotional gaps, from high comedy to extreme pathos. The George Gershwin music adds to the story that to me, as an outsider, defines Manhattan lifestyle. I believe it was somewhat overlooked because it followed the extremely popular "Annie Hall." This one is better.

Still not "The Purple Rose of Cairo" (which is vastly underrated in my view).  "Manhattan" is vibrant and elegantly shot.  It is deeply heartfelt - the scene in which Isaac is lying on the couch listing the reasons why life, for him, is worth living was one of the finest scenes ever.  Mariel Hemingway was wonderful - her Tracy was a great creation to begin with - a real, wise, not immature, but still young girl.  And the character was fleshed out beautifully in the performance.  "Manhattan" is a lovely picture postcard - an homage to a legendary city, a fresh meditation on this tricky life/love business each of us has to go through.  But, as I've already written, for the greatest examination of love Allen has ever conceived, see "The Purple Rose of Cairo."  And then see "Manhattan."  Both are luminous.

Manhattan is truly a work of art. From an emotional point of view, this film has more resonance than, say, Annie Hall, or Sweet and Lowdown, although those two films had plenty of emotion. Manhattan was clearly made by someone who just loves making films, and it shows. Woody Allen's love affair with New York is obviously on display here, and this movie contains his absolute his finest shots. And he doesn't hedge his bets with the shots in this movie, from the wide expansive shots of the city to the way he incorporates the set, to the way he takes advantage of spacial orientation, this film contains Allen's most interesting work from a purely technical point of view. There's nothing that's clever-clever like in Annie Hall, all the interesting shots in Manhattan serve to increase the emotional impact, and the film is quite interesting to look at simply for the way he frames almost every shot. The characters and the story in this movie are also wonderful, as is the music, all George Gershwin tunes. Manhattan is truly one of the great cinematic achievements of the 20th century is one of the best movie's I've ever seen.

Manhattan is a truly amazing film from Woody Allen. It has everything anyone could want from a movie: it's funny, witty, smart, beautiful, romantic, yet also very emotionally devastating. It's ultimately a movie about love, the loss of it, and what's truly important in life. It boasts some amazing directing work, great performances from the whole cast, as well as a look, sound, and feel that completely defines New York City. The story centers around five people and the relationships between each and every one of them. It shows how these relationships grow and change, which is really interesting to see. The standout performance in this film comes from Diane Keaton, who plays the role of an emotionally troubled divorcée who cant decide what exactly she wants out of life. Even though her world seems to be falling apart, and she talks in a completely pessimistic way, she always manages to charm the audience, as well as be the character in the film you're the most attached to emotionally. All of the other actors are just as astounding, and they really get into their characters and become a part of this movie. Even though the performances are great, the main draw of this movie is the direction. This is arguably Woody Allen's best directing ever, absolutely everything about it perfectly describes New York. The visual style (shot in all black and white to add to the effect), the way it's shot, the musical score, and the dialog are all incredibly beautiful, and this is truly the greatest love letter to New York ever to be put on film. This story is funny, romantic, but overall really heartbreaking and eye-opening. It teaches the all-important lesson that no matter how hard you search for love, the only person you're ever meant to be with is always someone that you let go. However, the way it goes about reaching this conclusion is not at all cheesy, mostly because the performances are so incredibly convincing. Overall, this is a beautiful and brilliant movie, truly one of the first great romantic comedies. From the genius opening scene right down to the end credits, this is truly a masterpiece of cinema that should be essential viewing for all film lovers, or for people who simply love Manhattan.

This is one big spoiler, so don't bother reading this if you don't want part of the movie to be ruined.  Sorry.So, I had just watched Interiors with a friend and remarked that the problem I had with the majority of existentialism films and characters is that they make everything so depressing.  Now I love Crimes & Misdemeanors.  It is one of the greatest existential movies ever made, but damn, if it isn't depressing.  Alright, I understand that the world can be a horrible place. I understand that life doesn't play fair.  I'll even concede that there are no rules to life except those that we make.  But why would people continue if this is how they see life?My standpoint has always been that existentialism doesn't have to be depressing.  If you look at it from the standpoint that each moment is precious because there is nothing afterwards, it makes each moment of joy meaningful because it is simply that - joy.  Therefore the reasons to continue living are those things that bring you joy.  And the hope of future joy.What Woody Allen has done with Manhattan is bring that theory to life. Unlike his other serious existential movies (Interiors and Crimes & Misdemeanors) he uses his humor to show that joy.  And in the end when he realizes what will make him happy he jumps at it.  And like life, it isn't easily obtained.  It has to come through hope.  And trust.  And patience.Woody said that after the success of Annie Hall and the complete harsh objectiveness of Interiors he wanted to use the humor of Annie Hall to bring out the important messages he had to say with Interiors.  With Manhattan he did that beautifully.  And although I think there might be too much humor, it is one of the best movies to deal with human nature from an existential viewpoint ever made.It is one of my favorite movies.  It was a joy to watch it.  There's no higher praise than that.

Ah yes another night another movie to watch.  So I pop in "Manhattan", a movie I rented just because I needed to catch up on my Woody Allen.  I'm sort of new to the whole Allen thing I've only seen "Sleeper"(Great comedy) and one of his newer films, "Hollywood Ending", where he plays the blind director.  So I'm not an Allen nut in the least.  Haled by many as a great visionary, Woody Allen makes movies that are well put together and done very well.  This movie, well this movie has great composition. Excellent composition and if you want to watch a movie because of that go ahead. If you want to find a movie that will have you rolling on the floor laughing go watch "Sleeper". "Manhattan"is pretty much a movie showing what is great about Manhattan, and what can sometimes suck about it, if you are a well to do upper middle class citizen.  I enjoyed seeing the city more then I liked watching Allen and his 17 year old girlfriend.  I tend to agree with Meryl Streep's character about who Allen's character is, a self absorbed complainer. Allen does well with these types of characters, he seems to play them a lot. When I think about it though, if I was the Woody Allen Character, I would complain a lot too.  Anyway I watched this movie expecting to see a classic, I ended up disappointed.  Don't get caught up in the hype, if you can enjoy this movie do it if you can't then don't worry its only an hour and a half of your life wasted.

The last week I saw Manhattan I was wondering with the dialogs. I remembered the Oscar Wilde's novels. Woody Allen as a screenwriter is amazing!! I never saw nothing like this. Congratulations! The use of the Black and white is good and the way to show the high society and their style of life. With a few words you can understand the motivations of each character. The rhythm of the plot is constant very energetic but the middle part of the movie. In any case the global rhythm is very good. Finally, I am expecting to see more film of Mr. Woody Allen.PD:Spectacular Rhapsody in Blue combined with NY skylines.

This is Woody's Allen's picturesque look at Manhattan.  With Gershwin's score and the beautiful b&w photography, Allen has created something that Hollywood couldn't produce with a thousand other directors.  It is ironic that the story seems to parallel his current life style, but the fact remains that this is his best film to date.  A genius at work.

Gershwin´s score gives life to this city. Perfectly expresses Allen´s philosophy, humor, and ability to create interesting characters. The story is great, incredibly portraying disfunctional but realistic relationships between people. The black and white photography is beautiful. Mariel Hemmingway shines. The mostly pretty Diane Keaton looks ugly in that hairdo. And the start and end sequences with the shots from ny and the Gershwin music sent chills down my spine.

One of the greatest movies ever!!! Allen has made many excellent films, but this one is his BEST BY FAR!! Ironical, witty, melancholical, a wonderful composition in black and white - I guess, Allen teaches what you can do in this style. And its fascinating since decades. Issac`s relationship to his former wife...his confused looking for a new partnership - its as update as it was in the 70ies, and its more funny.

Simply a film I can never tire of watching again and again...the humour is deliciously subtle, the photography breathtaking and the performances absolutely spot-on. Despite the recent tragedy in the city this film still evokes a desire to go there, to witness just what it is that makes N.Y.C the most exciting city on earth (and speaking as an exiled Londoner that is saying something!).Woody can infuriate some and delight others, I'm glad I belong to the latter camp. As long as there are film makers like him, Martin Scorsese, the Coens, Wong Kar-Wai, David Lynch, David Fincher and Bryan Singer then we are guaranteed films which not only entertain but also require a little intellectual work to be done. How many Hollywood formula fodder can say that? Does that make me sound like a Woody Allen-type character snob? You bet!

reviews.review_title: Doesn't stand the test of time
reviews.content: I remember this film fondly, the cinematography, the Gershwin music, the witty repartee. But the theme of love, with changing partners, is not well exposed and with the hindsight that comes from Allen's own life, of the Allen character's affair with a 17 year old where much of the time is spent boasting of his sexual prowess is at best distasteful.And what are we to make of the end when he returns to his now 18 year old having been left by Diane Keaton, his recently acquired love, who herself returns to his best friend? The abuse his ex-wife has heaped on him in a memoire is it turns out generous. His behaviour is disgusting and unredeemed by even a good joke. As Allen hints, we would have found ourselves in a funnier and more morally grounded playbook if it had been written by Noel Coward.

I first watched Manhattan in Glasgow in 1979 and it knocked me out. While not enamoured so much by the music and setting, I love the wit and the critique of pseudo-intellectualism. The climax exposes the shallowness of Isaak and the 'maturity' of the now 18 year-old Tracy. Watchable time after time this ranks as my favourite along with Schindler's List but for very different reasons.

Like a connosiuer of fine wines, who takes great enjoyment in finding a new, great vintage, I take great pride in finding a new, great film.  Seeing a great film excites me, can even make my day ten times better than it would be, otherwise.  Finding the film is almost as great as the enjoyment i get from watching it.  I consider myself to be a true film fan, who has come to expect a lot from movies.  The first time i saw "manhattan" I was struck by the opening shot.  It is far different from anything else Woody Allen has done.  Being a director, I tend to hold originality far higher than any comedic value this film may offer.  I also tend to look at films a bit differently than most other people i know, that is, people i know not in the business.  The thing that makes Manhattan so much better than anything else Woody Allen has done, is the fact that it has it's own, unique style. Now, put the fact that it is shot in black and white behind you, as it is unimportant stylistically speaking.  (Woody Allen also shot a film called 'zelig' in black and white a year later, therefore destroying any credibility he may have gotten from me for that original move)  The film moves through the scenes as if it weren't shot by Woody Allen at all, moreover, it looks like something a professional director might shoot. Overall, this film is great because of the style, and originality that probably wasn't intended to be there in the first place.

Woody Allen's "Manhattan" it's without any doubt one of the greatest's movies of all time, each little thing works perfect on this picture, every dialog was full of intelligence and sarcasm, but also at the same time romantic and quite pessimist,after all it's an Allen's movie. The film(I don't know if it's necessary told that cause everybody knows)was started by Diane Keaton(it's always a pleasure sow her on screen), Mariel Hemningway(adorable and sexy too)and, of course, the best neurotic of all time, Woody himself. I don't wont to tell much of the story because I don't know if you see or not the film yet( if the answer it's "no" please run quickly to your video club right now)but in a few lines we could said that's the story of a middle-age men who after two divorces it's now in a period of his life were he don't know exactly what he wont, he had been seeing a young girl but he don't take the things that going on too seriously, but suddenly all the things of his life had been approach to change from a day to another. But what I really adore of this film, more than any other, was four things:1)the aperture sequence with the gershwing's soundtrack, 2)the black and withe as a way to express a particular perspective of art and life with all it's circumstances, 3)the city in all of his dimensions as anyone could showing after or later and, of course, 4)the brilliant scene were Woody was lied on the couch and, with a record tape turned on, stars to mention all the things in life for what really worth to live up to. In retrospective we are in conditions to confirm that no other picture was so personal and popular at the same time, and the truth is that maybe no other filmmaker made a tribute to the city that he loves(that's all in the monologue of the beginning)and teach us to love it too.

Quite likely Woody's masterpiece, a moving, funny film with a marvelous script by Allen, a wonderful score by George Gershwin, and terrific cinematography by Gordon Willis. Supported by a strong ensemble cast, featuring Diane Keaton perhaps the best American actress working, Manhattan is a masterpiece. The "Chapter One" opening segment is a beautifully funny scene, made better by the soundtrack. A filmic masterpiece and one of the best movies made during the seventies, Manhattan is a near-perfect film. The wry humor only contributes.

My 2022 commitment to see every movie featuring Meryl Streep continues.

In 1979 she appeared in Manhattan, playing the ex-wife of Woody Allen's character.

The Gershwin soundtrack was sublime and the black-and-white cinematography of 1970's Manhattan was a buffet for the eyes.

Now I need to go take a shower to get the stench of 96 minutes of Woody Allen repeatedly talking about his sexual prowess as he dates an underage girl (Mariel Hemingway) and hangs out with his unpleasant friends off of me.
Uninteresting confused movie that was a chore to get through.

My favorite Allen to date. I still find it hard to encompass the whole movie in one review with just two viewings, but everything I've grasped works for me. Brilliant cinematography thanks to an essential black & white; legendary soundtrack from the very first scene; typical Allen's wit at its finest distilled into a relentless screenplay; morally compelling and romantically universal. This masterpiece speaks to me, and it's hella fascinating to hear what it has to say. I'd watch it all again just to see Tracy paralyzed by her emotions around the end of the movie. We are but hostages of passions.

Allen's Manhattan is a director's lovingly idealized depiction of New York City, with glossy black and white cinematography making the landscape seem polished and ethereal. Towering buildings loom and landmarks stand like vaunted monuments; while the grime can't really be avoided in any depiction of New York ca. 1980, it's downplayed and treated like an oddly cherished part of the city's identity. At one point, we trail along behind a white Mustang as it cruises (alone) near the Hudson, listening in on the conversation between the passengers 30 feet ahead. There's no ambient noise, no traffic, no echoes from ten million other lives. It may not be realistic, but it does certainly look great. 

In this somewhat fictionalized playground of the intelligentsia steps Woody Allen as Isaac Davis, the next name given to the same personality that Allen does in most of classics - fretful, highly educated, verbose, and with a sardonic wit. But that's because his character works so well, and is pretty much endlessly entertaining. Isaac forms the centerpiece of a network of current and former lovers, friends, and colleagues who explore the possibilities of companionship through a series of small-scale encounters and everyday meetings where their sincere discussions are intermixed with heavy doses of humor and sarcasm. The roles are all well-played enough for the film to function as a straight-up comedy, but as the runtime rolls on you begin to see that there is an emotional depth behind it all - nobody is sure of themselves, everyone is making it up as they go along, and the passions are fickle. In this carefully photographed NYC that is beautifully accentuated by the musical talents of George Gershwin, there is a commentary on love and life that will end up hitting surprisingly hard after getting you to let your guard down with some great comedy.

Then you get thrown off by the middle-aged Allen having an openly sexual relationship with a 17-year-old girl, and you've got to spend the rest of your day muttering about how "it was a different time," so you can keep liking the film. (4/5)
only one of the greatest, most iconic movies ever made. Gamechanger of gamechangers. Woody Allen is a genius!
A smart, funny, poignant and romantic movie that feels bad due to recent Woody Allen acusations.

Easily one of the very best films of the 1970s. Woody Allen confidently keeps the comedy and drama in perfect balance while coaxing luminous turns from Diane Keaton, Meryl Streep & Mariel Hemingway. George Gershwin's legendary music combined with Gordon Willis' genius black and white cinematography perfectly captures New York's energy and essence; it will never again be this romantic.

Impressive movie. Was sceptical about it first but was won over by its mesmerizing cinematography, its charm, interesting intellectual in a not-boring way dialogues and its ultimate optimism. Every character is distinct and so it gives more interest in watching them interact with each other. The character of Hemingway eventually wins the prize as the most humane.
Woody Allen and Diane Keaton together is just delightful to watch, while the film is full of romanticism, laughs,  astonishing humor and gets that classic feeling.
Love letter to Manhattan and to an idealized Woody Allen to be linked to Diane Keaton, Mariel Hemingway and Meryl Streep

I find it extremely humorous how in every woody Allen movie he makes himself out to be some attractive desirable guy that all the woman like . He clearly has some narcissistic tendencies but he doesn’t seem to be the creep he’s made out to be 3

Manhattan is a 1979 American romantic comedy film directed by Woody Allen 🍿 

Here is Woody Allen in all of his glory. An intelligent screenplay and some amazing cinematography result in an enjoyable experience. 

It's ok, but I feel mixed about this one 😉

This is another fun romantic comedy by Woody Allen. I have started a long journey of watching all his movies and after 5 of them, I have to say that all were just so delightful to watch. Manhattan was no different: it is fun, it has a good story, great dialogues and beautiful scenes of his beloved Manhattan. Isaac Davis is the main character here (played by Woody, who mastered in playing this similar character over and over), a 40 years old comedy writer that divorced twice and now continues to look for the one relationship of his life. He is currently dating a 17 year old girl who seems to adore him and with whom he seems to feel very safe and just himsef. In this relationship he is the experimented one who is in control of things, he seems to consider this as a temporary thing until he is able to find someone with a proper age. This already hints the feeling that shows up constantly in the movie: people expect to know what they want and feel, who they love more and selfishly chose the best option. Of course, reality is much more complicated than that. Yale, Isaac's close friend, has a marriage of more than a decade but is having his third affair with a woman named Mary. They clearly have strong feelings for each other but also feel a (hypocrite?) guilt for the secret relationship. Isaac meets Mary and, while he is completely annoyed in their first interaction by her intelectual arrogance, it already seems that they will be together at some point. As Yale struggles to find time to be with his mistress, Isaac starts to fill that role and gets involved with Mary as their first encounter suggested. After that, the movie goes on to show us more of the feeling pointed out before as people seem to be so concerned about finding their true love (maybe just true for some time) that hurting the others envolved becomes just an inevitable consequence. The turn of events then is as much unpredictable (at least to me) as the connection between Mary and Isaac was on the first encounter, showing how good directors might even use apparently predictable moments at their favor. Woody's direction in fact is one I am starting to appreciate a lot; I loved the initial scenes of Manhattan while he starts his book (already so indecisive about love and how to describe it), the shots that resembles old silent films are also very interesting and the length of most scenes just blew my mind (it must be a true test for good actors). The movie has a nice and simple story which is told at an amazing rythm that just feels like it is how it was supposed to be (no boring sections at all), there are several funny moments as usual, dialogues are simple but sharpe and entertaining and the beautiful wide shots of Manhattan just complete the whole thing. It might not be the most amazing film but what is not to love?
Really uncomfortable, Mariel Hemingway is the only high point.

Manhattan Pros: Fantastic Acting Amazing Directing Outstanding Writing Striking Cinematography Magnificent Editing Excellent Musical Score Brilliant Pacing Superb Storytelling Mixes comedy and drama well Sublime chemistry between each actor Cons: The storyline has a couple of predictable moments here and there Overall Grade: A (9.5/10)

But I see a movie that, when I first viewed it in college, made me pretty uneasy. Woody Allen with a beautiful girl was hard to understand. It didn't make sense. And then, there it is on the big screen in black and white. He gets girls that are pretty and younger -- so young that it's illegal -- so that he has power over them.

Black and white just doesn't cut it.  The world is in color, why isn't the movie?  No young person wants to watch a movie such as this, and it is particularly galling because color was the standard film choice when the movie was made.  I do not agree with people who say that limiting the shots to black and white somehow "improve" the movie.  It may make it easier for the cinematographer and for Allen's storytelling, but it does nothing to illuminate or move along the story.  As a postcard this may work, but as a movie, something fluid and meant to be living, it is limiting and short-sighted.  A very poor choice that cannot be supported rationally.  It meaningfully detracts from the movie.

A love letter to the city in the first few minutes, then the movie itself, Manhattan had many of the subtle one-liners we associate with Woody ("You're so beautiful I can barely keep my eyes on the [taxi] meter." was probably my favorite) but was just missing something more for me to push it into the 80s. Isaac (Woody Allen), forty-two and dating a seventeen-year-old definitely didn't age well, even if she (Mariel Hemingway) is the most mature character in the movie. And that might be the biggest issue I had with Manhattan, is that the main cast of characters are largely unlikable in a generally likeable movie. I suppose it's a microcosm of a piece of NYC that still exists today; successful, egotistical, neurotic people making problems for themselves, spending too much on rent, and looking at art. I also could've moved it into the 80s with a better ending. It was so shitty how Isaac treated Tracy, only for the film to want us to want them together in the end. It did give us that gorgeous shot of the Queensboro Bridge, however, even if the bench was never really there.

Oscar-nominated story by Allen & Marshall Brickman examine impossible relationships and guilt complexes with witty humor and touching emotion. Irony, good acting and soundtrack always make a movie worth watching. And Manhattan can boast the best here . 8/10

One of the definitive love letters to New York City this is a film that provided an aspirational vision of adulthood to me at a young age as troubling as that thought was when revisiting the film. Watching the film now I see that it was as brilliant as I thought it was when I first saw it but in different ways as I was now able to look past the glamour of a group of highly intelligent people having conversations about art in a beautiful location to see how lonely all of these people were despite their talents and position in life. I no longer aspire to be divorced and can see that suffering is painful even if you look attractive or have seen several art films. With this ability to look past the surface attractions of the film I could see how it delved into the emotional confusion that people experience when they reach a certain point in their lives and begin to feel lonely.

Television writer Isaac Davis, Woody Allen, has left his job ostensibly to write a boom but struggles to formulate ideas. He wallows in the pains he experienced during his relationship with his ex-wife Jill, Meryl Streep, who left him for her lesbian lover and is now writing a tell all book about their marriage. In trying to find himself he has fallen into a relationship with the sexually explorative teenager Tracy, Mariel Hemingway, who he attempts to break up with repeatedly. He eventually leaves her when he falls in love with a woman his own age in the damaged Mary Wilkie, Diane Keaton, who happens to be the former mistress of his married best friend Yale Pollack, Michael Murphy. Davis and Wilkie break up when she returns to Pollack and Davis finds himself alone despite trying to reconcile with Tracy.

For some this could be considered a better film than Annie Hall (1977), although I still like that film more, as it presents the audience with a tougher ending in that this man never really loved any of the women he was romantically involved with. His relationship with Jill was based on his physical desire for her as he often describes her as attractive while failing to take into account her combative personality or lack of attraction to him. Tracy is a girl that he uses to try to recapture his youth as he remains immature even though he knows about classic films and enjoys wielding a certain power over his inexperienced girlfriend while also having an ‘equal' in terms of maturity in many ways. Finally he falls into a romance with the equally tragic Wilkie who has her heart set on various men who she can not commit to because they either overwhelm her or do not provide her with enough of their time. She is shown to throw herself wholeheartedly into a relationship at it's beginning before backing away for fear of being hurt as all of the rejection she has experienced in previous relationships is recalled. He is not satisfied in his relationships with any of these women and is in a perpetual state of discontent as he wants what the other women can provide when he is with one of his love interests.

Why is it then that this sad little story of a weak man who does not understand his desires or needs makes New York City look so glorious? Mixed in amongst the depressing story and troubled characters are scenes in which characters visit the landmarks of the city which are seen in glorious black and white and set to a score full of classic songs. The opening and closing montages featuring shots of New York City feel exactly like what one imagines when they think of a stereotypical Woody Allen film and for good reason because few directors have the knowledge of the city that he does. There is one spectacular scene in which Allen and Keaton wander through a museum exhibit set in the solar system and without seeing their faces we understand exactly how each of them feels as they consider starting a relationship before he hesitates. Where the films of other New York directors focus on gangsters or plain middle class families Allen aims for insecure upper class Manhattanites who concern themselves with The Grand Illusion (1937) and Kierkegaard. It is too easy to be taken in by these people as they seem to know everything about culture and speak with authority but underneath all of this Allen tells us that even those living in the greatest city on earth can feel hurt, rejection and even love.
On par with his previous masterpiece Annie Hall Woody Allen's study of love life amidst New York intellectuals scores  with beautiful b&w cinematography and more subtle humor than before.
A great beginning, a mediocre middle, and a terrific ending.

A perfect film. All of Woody’s genius, warmth, intellect, cynicism and humor in one of the best films of the 70’s. I’ve converted those who profess to ‘hate Woody Allen movies’ with this one.

Manhattan tells a tale that is funny and romantic, even agonizing at times, but it never looses its optimistic core. Woody creates a web of relationships that are all so tangible and therefore make it hard for you not to relate to any of them.

Actually I'm disappointed because the movie didn't answer a lot of question, such as:

* How on earth the tone slips so gracefully between the gut-busting one-liners and emotionally exhausting romantic moments like that?

* How can a black-and-white film still be considered as one of the most beautiful movies ever with its gorgeous cinematography?

* How can a 96 min film has such character development? * How can a single quote make a lot of change to the characters and the story itself?

* How can a soundtrack that features only the rhythms of songs can speak for the hero at every stage he get through?  * How can a movie this complex and presents messages about love and loss seems to be so simple that can be rewatched. .... and many more questions left unanswered.

I’d like to go on record in saying that I am pretty good at keeping my opinions about actors’ personal lives completely separate from my opinions of the films they make (and frankly I don’t know enough about whatever scandals Woody Allen has been involved in to form a strong opinion anyways.) But what his character does in a film I’m perfectly willing to judge. I struggled early with Manhattan because statutory rape just isn’t something I’m capable of chuckling about. This movie asks me to see it as no big deal and a genuine relationship I’m supposed to enjoy. Not only was the main character actively involved in this inappropriate relationship, everyone around him reacts to it with casual acceptance. When I tried to compartmentalize this one aspect of the film, I still didn’t find myself laughing much. The humor is mostly built around Woody Allen’s neurotic personality, and his struggle in romantic relationships. I liked the cast, and the actors do have good comedic timing, but few of the jokes resonated with me enough to get me laughing . I was annoyed by the fact that the characters were pretty despicable, and everyone made the worst decisions. As a result, I didn’t like anybody in Manhattan at all. Plus Woody Allen made the pretentious decision to film it all in black-and-white for no discernible reason. Manhattan is basically all the things I dislike about other Woody Allen movies all rolled into one. I’ve seen worse comedies, but Manhattan did little to interest me.

I love Manhattan even more than I do Annie Hall. I think this has incredible themes off love, regret and maturity. The movie also looks beautiful, the cinematography of New York in black and white was truly stunning. The performances were terrific from the whole cast. Woody Allen is his usual negative self but more lovable and his comic timing is spot on here. As is Diane Keaton's, you can't take your eyes off here in this movie. Director/screenwriter Woody Allen strikes gold once again in this glamourized, self-satisfying depiction of several lives and their relationships with one another in contemporary (late 1970s) Manhattan. Cast includes Woody Allen at his most neurotic and hyperanalytical, Diane Keaton at her most abrasive and concealed, Meryl Streep at her most fed up and antipathetic, Mariel Hemingway at her brightest and most easygoing, and Michael Murphy at his most cocksure and seesawy. Fragile, dry humour deflates the grandest romantic gestures committed in this story, and, without ever coming close to preaching, confronts the viewer with a necessary deconstruction and reconstruction of romance, commitment, and separation.

Well, petty distractions turned watching this movie into an 8 hour extravaganza of rewinding and replaying, but it delivered despite how I watched it. Woody Allen makes me feel better about life. Always. I love his masterful delivery of moving art, I love his storytelling, I love his depth, I love that I can always relate to him and like him no matter what horrible things people are doing to each other in the movie, and I love that he gives that perspective to acknowledge that people are just people and are going to be fallible but can still be beautiful and loveable and worthy full fledged humans, flaws and all.  I loved the movie in its entirety, but as always with me it comes down to the ending being what makes or breaks a movie, and this ending was beautiful. When I'm at my lowest, multiple Woody Allen movies have reminded me that life is still worthwhile, and I'm glad this was one of those. I needed it. It's weird when someone speaks to your soul and you know you'll never get the opportunity to thank them.

A brilliant romance between New York (Diane Keaton) and Allen, who masterfully portrays both one's natural love for, and natural longing to leave New York City. Allen's use of black and white filming and Rhapsody in Blue in the beginning underscores the idea of people over romanticizing the city, and also explains the unanimous love for New York City. However, just like in his relationship with Tracy (Mariel Hemingway) Allen wants to break away, and move on. A beautiful parallel. Allen also accurately portrays the personality of many New Yorkers.

As somebody with a father who grew up in New York City, this line couldn't be more accurate. Truly the New Yorker way.

When films such as Manhattan and Citizen Kane are regarded as great achievements, I begin to feel as if some mechanism is not functioning in my brain, or perhaps is over-functioning in everybody else's. 

This is the story of a bunch of boring, unlikable, over educated but under-scientific privileged white people trying to create sexual relationships with each other.  Who cares?  Why do people enjoy these movies?  It didn't teach me anything, none of the character's behavior seemed admirable  or interesting.  

This movie reminds me of weak and asinine people, and doesn't do George Gershwin's music any justice.  (Although the brief dialogue about Gustav Mahler being overrated is the only thing that I resonated with in the film).  

I'm going back to studying physics and listen to Beethoven now.  Bye.

A stunning visual poem on the unique beauty of Woody's home Manhattan, the introduction of his first post-Oscar comedy is a loving tribute. The entire film is shot in black & white with an abundance of gorgeous photography throughout. Allen plays another New York writer who gets involved with a complicated woman, this time it's after she ends her affair with his best friend. Allen & Keaton both do an excellent job, as do Meryl Streep & Mariel Hemingway (who earned an Oscar nod), but all that is distracted by the one major flaw of this otherwise great film. Playing a 42 year old writer dating a 17 year old girl. At the time I'm sure it was odd at the time, but with all the rumors & allegations we have now about his private life, it's kind of unsettling to watch. He calls it out immediately at the beginning of the movie to normalize it but I doubt most people will ever be comfortable with his May/December choice. Of course, he leaves her for a woman that challenges him intellectually but Freud could have a field day with this. I find the ending to be completely false and unrewarding. Considering that this is Allen's least favorite of his own work I'm sure he agrees.

Manhattan is a self-referential, self-deprecating if not an autobiographical work of Woody Allen. Focusing to a group of problematic and complex people in a sentimental urban setting, Manhattan offers more complexity and sentimentality than Annie Hall, although both of them were built on really similar blueprints. It is also brutally honest with abundant numbers of Freudian jokes and psychoanalysis.
This is Woody Allen at his finest.

Teeming with both genuine pathos and sheer hilarity, Manhattan is Woody Allen at the pinnacle of his considerable prowess and is only made more brilliant by its gorgeous cinematography and the beauty of the city is so dearly admires.

New York City is perhaps the only character large enough to overshadow Allen's trademark narcissism, and it appropriately stars in this film which encompasses byproducts of urban living, young adulthood, liberal self indulgence, and social exposition, fused together by an eye for city beauty, a reverence for history, and a timeless modern pulse.

Manhattan is a deserving classic. Allen's subversive script is used well in context and creates a well established system in which Allen delightfully tears down. The whole film is rough like Manhattan itself but just alike it contains a beautiful core.

From a stylish perspective, Manhattan presents a large step out for Woody Allen's tradition of filmmaking. It does not incorporate the same visual or story style to his trademark comic pieces as the film is more comedy-drama yet maintains the same form of atmosphere he establishes in a lot of his films. And in terms of visual style, the cinematography in the film is a lot more atmospheric as it takes on a wider range of angles and incurs more movement and editing than the standard piece. It establishes a feeling of isolation in the atmosphere for viewers and gives them a sense of peeking in on the underside of people's lives. This gives Manhattan a new level of complex depth to it and stronger meaning, and it allows the drama of the film to flourish. And the black and white style of the film gives it an interesting sense of nostalgia. It evokes memories to a much simpler time of cinema, and considering that Manhattan is a rather simple and easy film to watch. The black and white colour palette of the film and lighting evoke a truly classical feel, and that is a great thematic for a Woody Allen film because it makes it all the more meaningful coming from him, as if it is a stylish homage to the films he grew up with. The classical style of the musical score helps to add to this, so Manhattan really is an interesting experience.
Manhattan has the naturally lighthearted feel to it which makes it an easy viewing pleasure. It is not one of Woody Allen's funnier films, but the quality of the comedy in it is fine and it blends with the drama really well. Admittedly it is a rather familiar film in terms of subject matter, but it is still a touching sentiment which is crafter really well with a strong screenplay. The complicated exploration of relationships in Manhattan are an all new angle of exploration for Woody Allen. He has a natural knack for it, and in Manhattan he incorporates it with a new style of filmmaking. It is a very ambitious film, and while it is familiar and relatively slow in pace as well as so realistic in narrative that its drama can only hit a certain level of strength, it is an enjoyable experience. It is a gentle film with a lot of touching plot dynamics to it, although I feel that there is certain predictability to it. It is different to the predictability of a lot of his films as they tend to follow a formula. The thing about Manhattan is that the ending of the film is inevitable, and is somewhat of a letdown. Considering that it is another film about the relationship between characters played by Woody Allen and Diane Keaton, it has an ending to similar to Annie Hall from the preceding year. Both films are good, although Manhattan fails to reach the heights of Annie Hall. It is more stylish, but the fact that the ending is so similar makes it slightly disappointing. Considering the unpredictable nature of the film it would be hard to pick a perfect ending, but I guess I just felt that the one in Manhattan was a letdown which was a bit too similar to Annie Hall. But still, a lot of the other elements that Manhattan borrows from Annie Hall are good.
And thanks to a fine cast, Manhattan remains a solid film on a human level.
Woody Allen plays out a character less like his stereotypical nebbish than in many of his other films. This time he tones down to Jewish shtick and focuses more on a character who seems naturally like him. His performance is realistic and easily likable which makes the frequently cartoonish character a more humane one. This makes the sympathy in the film a lot stronger as the protagonist is one that audiences will more likely care about. Woody Allen's subtle comic approach to the material and legitimate dramatic work is just grand in Manhattan which makes it one of his greatest leading performances, and his chemistry with every other actor, particularly Diane Keaton, is just wonderful. I was thoroughly impressed with his leading performance in Manhattan as it is very far from indulgent.
Diane Keaton does a fine job in Manhattan as well. She conveys a great sense of confusion and unpredictability in the role which makes her an intriguing character. Her emotional confusion contributes a great part to the film's exploration of complicated love in relationships, and she pulls it off really easily. Her role is ripe with charisma and finely dramatic without ever descending to melodrama or any sort of cheap comic ploy. She steps away from her iconic Annie Hall role to deliver another excellent performance in a Woody Allen film, so her presence as the leading actress is very welcome.
Mariel Hemingway proves to make herself a likable foil in Manhattan as well. She has a youthful spirit to her and her chemistry with Woody Allen is just great. She is sweet, and in her young age she is easily able to work the best out of Woody Allen's script which is impressive as it is such complex stuff. She makes a name for herself very well in Manhattan, and despite a small period of screen time she is easily memorable.
Meryl Streep also delivers an early performance in Manhattan where viewers get to see her talents from the same year when she won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress in Kramer vs. Kramer. Her brief appearance contributes some grand moments to the film, so she is really genial.

So Manhattan is a rather slow film with a somewhat unsatisfactory  ending and a sense of familiar themes, but it is powerfully stylish, touching and extremely well-acted which makes use of all of Woody Allen's greatest talents.

The first time I viewed "Manhattan" in high school, it repulsed me in a way that I couldn't put into words. After giving it a second look, I now see that I perceived it to be Allen's declaration of his own self-absolution, an embracing of his deeply flawed nature (the 17 year-old love interest specifically), when in actuality it proves to be less of Allen forgiving himself of his sins and more of his own self-flagellation. The perfect rendering of New York, the sentimental and nostalgic social-construct of an idea of New York, is intoxicating and emotionally mirrors his sense of self, the two irreparably fused and co-dependent at the same time. With a bittersweet tone, wealth of critical insight, and impeccable production, "Manhattan" is a masterpiece, and rivals only the great "Annie Hall" for the title of Allen's most perfect work.

Review:
This movie is definitely a tribute to New York City. The scenery looks great throughout the film and the black and white theme, really does work. As for the movie itself, it just seemed like your typical Woody Allen movie, which are usually about relationships between friends and lovers. For 1979, this must have been a unique movie because of its mixture between comedy and serious relationship issues, which we all can relate to, but for this day and age, we have seen this type of film many times before. The relationship between Woody and the young girl was interesting, along with the ex-wife, played by Meryl Streep, whose become a lesbian after having a child with Woody, so there's enough material to keep the movie watchable. Personally, it does go down as some of his best work because he got everything right, but I'm still struggling to get his humour. Watchable!

Round-Up:
After watching some of Woody Allen's later work, I can see why everyone rated his earlier on projects because he had a unique style of directing/writing which is very dry and offensive but in a joking type of way. Half of his jokes in his earlier movies, wouldn't be politically correct for modern times, which is why it's easier to stick with Romantic Comedies. Anyway, Mariel Hemingway put it a emotional and realistic performance, at such a young age, and the rest of the cast made the movie believable interesting.

We can all see part of ourselves in Isaac/Allen. The film is nostalgic, wistful, yet with no intention of depicting a story from a single lens or to a single destination. What truly clicked within me are the few subtle moments filled with Isaac's mumbling and his looking away. Allen said "he has no problem in meeting women", yet with some careful thought, we realized he has no problem drawing women's attention, but failed at maintaining them. As in "Chapter 1", New York meant beautiful women and street smart guys who know all the angles. Isaac is witty, but not in the same way as the street smart guys. The women Isaac met are all beautiful, yet they're not particularly after Isaac's gifts. With an identity crisis, Isaac holds too strong of an ideal that's most likely developed from unsuccessful attempts with women and life. An intangible ideal is perfect for escaping reality and putting oneself at a higher ground above anything else. Yet Isaac is just an ordinary guy, with a witty sense of humor, chasing after delicately decorated faces, shaped by modern advertising, only with a romantic touch of his own interpretations. Allen Woody was absolutely incredible at interpreting the character that has struck my emotions so hard with the subtle, delicate moments.

I found the whole thing more unsettling than funny, particularly Woody Allen's character's romance with a teen, perhaps in part due to recent allegations. That was just something I couldn't get over, and colored the whole viewing.

A great film shot entirely in black and white, that many people believe is Woody Allen's best. Stylistically, I would agree even if I think some of the black and white is too dark, though I'm pretty sure that's intentional. There are 4 separate love stories here, so if this gets confusing, just read the next few sentences over and over again til you get it. Woody is in love with two women, Diane Keaton and 17 year old Mariel Hemingway. There's two. Then there is Michael Murphy and Diane Keaton, the former being married and Woody's best friend. That's three. The 4th and final is the real Woody Allen's love affair with New York. This is by far the most interesting of all the love stories in this flick. The way the film is shot and written and by using Gershwin tunes as the final brush stroke, Woody paints a picture of his New York. It is very easily, a New York anyone can see themselves living in. While it's not my favorite and I tend to the story is basically the same one he always tells, I've learned to enjoy this film more over the years. Tho I wouldn't mind a Gershwin only audio track on a future release. So I can sit back and pretend I am in the Woody Allen's ideal heaven. New York City.

How can you not fall in love with New York City after watching a movie like this!  How can you not fall in love with its people?  Or what about the music.  "Manhattan" is a classic.  There's no question about it.  You find yourself swept away as you fall in love with two things at once, the movie and the city. The plot and Manhattan itself.  Woody Allen is so witty and brilliant.  The movie is so reflective of the vulnerabilities in real love.  It's reflective of the fact that when you really love someone you love them with all of their flaws.  You don't just love their good side, you love everything about them.  In this case that involves a girl as well as a city.  An excellent, breathtaking, fantastic, musical, and  classic tale of, well, Manhattan.
Romantic, funny, & beautiful. A great film about the nature of love in our bustling lives as only Woody Allen can show it.

People driven by self-destructive impulses due to a lack of maturity and direction, which leads to forest fires that they then try to put out with more fire causing a downward spiral of self-absorbed ever-escalating drama. 
It was best summed up by Woody Allen's ex-wife in her book telling all of their marriage and divorce. My rendition of it is my own observation. 
And then at the end there's a excellent summation of the lunacy of it all with the great simple wisdom, "It's very important to have some kind of personal integrity." 

The one with the greatest wisdom is the 17-year old played Mariel Hemingway.

Loved hearing of the psychoanalyst that goes into a coma due to a bad acid experience. There were some very funny scenes.  Listening to that and hearing of EST really grounded it in its time. Despite it being a 1979 New York film, it fortunately isn't weighted down with too many references of its time.  Also, the deep emotional and behavioral themes it deals with has it be entered into the cinematic annals as a timeless work of art. 

Presenting it in black and white works really well as a nice artistic touch.

Wry wit and romantic realism set against a blissful black-and-white backdrop ensure that love in the big apple never looked or felt so good, and though neither as zesty as Annie Hall or as enigmatic as Crimes & Misdemeanours, Allen's loveletter to the great metropolis begs repeat viewings and oozes cinematic charm.
